[[File:JesusCuresamute.gif|thumb|right|[[Jesus exorcising a mute|''Christ Exorcising a Mute'']] by [[Gustav Dore]], 1865.]]
'''Exorcism in Christianity''' is the practice of casting out [[Christian demonology|demons]] from a person they are believed to have [[Demonic possession|possessed]]. The person performing the [[exorcism]], known as an [[exorcist]], is often a member of the [[Christian Church]], or an individual thought to be [[Grace (Christianity)|graced]] with special powers or skills. The exorcist may use prayers and religious material, such as set formulas, [[gesture]]s, [[symbol]]s, [[icon]]s, [[amulet]]s, etc. The exorcist often invokes [[God in Christianity|God]], [[Jesus in Christianity|Jesus]] and/or several different [[angel]]s and [[archangel]]s to intervene with the exorcism. A survey of Christian exorcists found that most exorcists believe that any mature Christian can perform an exorcism, not just members of [[clergy]]. Christian exorcists most commonly believe the authority given to them by the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit (the [[Trinity]]) is the source of their ability to cast out demons.<ref>Mohr, M. D., & Royal, K. D. (2012). "Investigating the Practice of Christian Exorcism and the Methods Used to Cast out Demons", Journal of Christian Ministry, 4, p. 35. Available at: http://journalofchristianministry.org/article/view/10287/7073.</ref>
The term became prominent in [[Early Christianity]] from the early [[Christianity in the 2nd century|2nd century]] onward.<ref name="John Anthony McGuckin - Definition">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/?id=u4i8jv0b7IkC&pg=PA138&dq=orthodox+exorcism&cd=20#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism|quote= Exorcism From the Gree ''exorkizo'', "i adjure" (cf. Matt. 26:63), [[exorcism]] became a term prominent in early Christianity from the early 2nd century onward (cf. Justin, ''Dialogue with Trypho'' 76.6;85.2) as the casting out of devils.|title= The Westminster handbook to patristic theology|publisher =[[Westminster John Knox Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31|isbn = 978-0-664-22396-0|year = 2004}}</ref>
In general, [[Demonic possession|people considered to be possessed]] are not regarded as [[evil]] in themselves, nor wholly responsible for their actions, because possession is considered to be unwilling manipulation by a demon resulting in harm to self or others. Therefore, practitioners regard exorcism as more of a cure than a punishment. The mainstream rituals usually take this into account, making sure that there is no violence to the possessed, only that they be tied down if there is potential for violence.<ref>Malachi M. (1976) Hostage to the Devil: the possession and exorcism of five living Americans. San Francisco, Harpercollins p.462 {{ISBN|0-06-065337-X}}</ref>
==Old Testament== The ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' says that there is only one apparent case of demonic possession in the Old Testament, of King [[Saul]] being tormented by an "evil spirit" (1 Samuel 16:14), but it relies on an interpretation of the Hebrew word "rûah" as "evil spirit", an interpretation that is doubted by the ''Catholic Encyclopedia''.<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Demoniacal Possession}}</ref> The ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' ties exorcism methods mentioned in extra-canonical Jewish literature to the driving off of a demon in the book of Tobias.<ref name="CathEncy|wstitle=Exorcism">{{CathEncy|wstitle=Exorcism}}</ref> Some theologians such as Ángel Manuel Rodríguez say that [[Mediumship|mediums]] like the ones mentioned in Leviticus 20:27 were possessed by demons.<ref>{{cite|author=Ángel Manuel Rodríguez|title=Old Testament demonology|journal=Ministry: International Journal for Pastors|volume=1998 (7:6)|pp=5-7|url=https://www.ministrymagazine.org/archive/1998/06/old-testament-demonology|accessdate=October 29, 2017}}</ref>
==New Testament== {{See also|Miracles of Jesus#Exorcisms}} Christian exorcism is founded on the belief that Jesus commanded his followers to expel evil spirits in [[Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament|his name]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Matthew|10:1}},{{bibleverse||Matthew|10:8}}; {{bibleverse||Mark|6:7}}; {{bibleverse||Luke|9:1}}{{bibleverse-nb||Luke|10:17}}, {{bibleverse||Mark|16:17}}</ref> According to the [[Catholic Encyclopedia]] article on Exorcism, Jesus points to this ability as a sign of his [[Messiah]]ship, and he empowered his [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciples]] to do the same.<ref name="CathEncy|wstitle=Exorcism"/>
The [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] traces the practice of exorcism to the Scriptural claim that [[Jesus Christ]] expelled demons with a simple command (Mark 1:23–26; 9:14–29; Luke 11:14–26).<ref name="LCMS-Exorcism">{{cite web|url = http://www.lcms.org/ca/www/cyclopedia/02/display.asp?t1=E&word=EXORCISM| title = Exorcism|publisher = Lutheran Church Missouri Synod|accessdate = 2009-05-27}}</ref> The [[Apostle (Christian)|apostles]] continued the practice with the power and in the name of Jesus (Matthew 10:1; Acts 19:11–16).<ref name="LCMS-Exorcism"/>
The [[Jewish Encyclopedia]] article on Jesus states that Jesus, "was devoted especially to casting out demons," and also believed that he passed this on to his followers; however, "his superiority to his followers was shown by his casting out demons which they had failed to expel."<ref>[http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=254&letter=J&search=jesus%20casting%20out%20demons#998 JewishEncyclopedia.com - JESUS OF NAZARETH<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==History==
===Early church=== [[St. Cyril of Jerusalem]] wrote, "Receive the exorcisms with devotion...Divine exorcisms, borrowed from the Scripture, purify the soul."<ref>{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/?id=J7abX63aB4IC&pg=PA44&dq=orthodox+exorcism&cd=16#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism|title=Orthodox Spirituality: An Outline of the Orthodox Ascetical and Mystical Tradition|quote=St. Cyril of Jerusalem writes: "Receive the exorcisms with devotion...Divine exorcisms, borrowed from the Scripture, purify the soul."|publisher =[[St Vladimir's Seminary Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31|isbn = 978-0-913836-51-4|year = 1978}}</ref>
===Middle Ages=== [[File:St. Francis Borgia Helping a Dying Impenitent by Goya.jpg|right|thumb|Painting by [[Francisco Goya]] of [[Saint Francis Borgia]] performing an exorcism.]]
The [[Order of Saint Benedict|Benedictine]] ''[[Vade retro satana]]'' was used in the medieval era.
In the 15th century, Catholic [[exorcists]] were both clerical and [[layman|lay]], since every Christian has the power to command demons and drive them out in the name of Christ.<ref name="Moshe Sluhovsky - Lay Exorcists">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/?id=fPGyeVQfgCUC&pg=PA43&dq=orthodox+exorcism&cd=12#v=onepage&q=lay%20exorcist|title=Believe Not Every Spirit: Possession, Mysticism, & Discernment in Early Modern Catholicism|quote= ...[[Johannes Nider]] and [[Heinrich Kramer]] found nothing wrong with the performance of exorcism by laypeople, as long as they did not usurp the clerical rite, which included some prayers only a priest could pronounce. Every Christian, Nider reminded his readers, had the power to command demons and drive them out in the name of Christ, but lay exorcists should be extremely careful not to use unknown characters and charms, and should be aware that the only mode to adjure demons is the imperative and never the supplicative.|publisher =[[University Of Chicago Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31|isbn = 978-0-226-76282-1|year = 2007}}</ref>
===Reformation=== After the [[Protestant Reformation]], [[Martin Luther]] abbreviated the Roman ritual used for exorcism.<ref name="Christian Classics Ethereal Library-Exorcism">{{cite web|url = http://www.ccel.org/s/schaff/encyc/encyc04/htm/ii.vii.htm| title = Exorcism|publisher = Christian Classics Ethereal Library|accessdate = 2009-05-27}}</ref> In 1526, the ritual was further abbreviated and the [[Insufflation|exsufflation]] was omitted. This form of the ''Lutheran Ritual for Exorcism'' was incorporated into the majority of the Lutheran service-books and implemented.<ref name="Christian Classics Ethereal Library-Exorcism"/><ref>{{cite book |last=Ferber|first=Sarah|title=Demonic possession and exorcism in early modern France|year=2004 |publisher=Routledge|page=38|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DNS5oatndpUC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=exorcism+lutheran|accessdate=2009-05-25|isbn=0-415-21265-0}}</ref>
==Current beliefs and practices==
===Anglicanism===
====Church of England==== In 1974, the Church of England set up the "[[Deliverance ministry]]".<ref name=batty1/> As part of its creation, every [[diocese]] in the country was equipped with a team trained in both exorcism and psychiatry. According to its representatives, most cases brought before it have conventional explanations, and actual exorcisms are quite rare; blessings, though, are sometimes given to people for psychological reasons.<ref name=batty1>{{cite news | last = Batty | first = David | date = 2001-05-02 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/society/2001/may/02/socialcare.mentalhealth1| title = Exorcism: abuse or cure? | work = Guardian Unlimited | accessdate = 2007-12-29 }}</ref>
Anglican [[priests]] may not perform an exorcism without permission from the Diocesan [[bishop]]. An exorcism is not usually performed unless the bishop and his team of specialists (including a [[psychiatrist]] and [[physician]]) have approved it.
====Episcopal Church==== In the [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopal Church]], the ''Book of Occasional Services'' discusses provision for exorcism; but it does not indicate any specific rite, nor does it establish an office of "exorcist".<ref>"Concerning Exorcism", ''Book of Occasional Services'', Church Publishing.</ref> Diocesan exorcists usually continue in their role when they have retired from all other church duties.
=== Baptists === [[Albert Mohler]], the ninth president of the [[Southern Baptist Theological Seminary]], states that [[Baptist]]s, among other [[evangelical Christians]], do {{quotation|believe in the existence, malevolence, and power of the Devil and demons. About these things, the New Testament is abundantly clear. We must resist any effort to 'demythologize' the New Testament in order to deny the existence of these evil forces and beings. At the same time, we must recognize quickly that the Devil and demons are not accorded the powers often ascribed to them in popular piety. The Devil is indeed a threat, as Peter made clear when he warned: 'Be sober-minded; be watchful. Your adversary the devil prowls around like a roaring lion, seeking someone to devour.' [1 Peter 5:8] The New Testament is also clear that very real cases of demonic possession were encountered by Jesus and his followers. Jesus liberated afflicted individuals as he commanded the demons to flee, and they obeyed him. Likewise, the Apostle Paul performed exorcisms as he confronted the powers of evil and darkness in his ministry. A closer look at the crucial passages involved reveals no rite of exorcism, however, just the name of Jesus and the proclamation of the Gospel. Likewise, there is no notion of a priestly ministry of ordained exorcists in the New Testament.<ref>{{cite web|title=On Exorcism and Exorcists: An Evangelical View|last=Mohler|first=Albert|date=15 November 2010|publisher=Southern Baptist Convention|accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref>}} As a result of this theology, for the Baptist Christian, the weapons of "warfare are spiritual, and the powers that the forces of darkness most fear are the name of Jesus, the authority of the Bible, and the power of his Gospel."<ref>{{cite web|title=On Exorcism and Exorcists: An Evangelical View|last=Mohler|first=Albert|date=15 November 2010|publisher=Southern Baptist Convention|accessdate=5 May 2014|quote=The weapons of our warfare are spiritual, and the powers that the forces of darkness most fear are the name of Jesus, the authority of the Bible, and the power of his Gospel.}}</ref>
===Catholicism=== [[File:Ottava di San Filippo d'Agira a Limina - Province of Messina, Sicily, Italy - Sunday 19 May 2013.jpg|thumb|The statue of Saint [[Philip of Agira]] with the [[Gospel]] in his left hand, the symbol of the exorcists, in the May celebrations in his honor at [[Limina]], [[Sicily]]]] {{main|Exorcism in the Catholic Church}} In Catholic [[dogma]] exorcism is a [[sacramentals|sacramental]] but not a [[Sacraments of the Catholic Church|sacrament]], unlike [[baptism]] or [[Confession (religion)|confession]]. Unlike a sacrament, exorcism's "integrity and efficacy do not depend ... on the rigid use of an unchanging formula or on the ordered sequence of prescribed actions. Its efficacy depends on two elements: authorization from valid and licit Church authorities, and the faith of the exorcist."<ref>Martin M. (1976) ''Hostage to the Devil: The Possession and Exorcism of Five Contemporary Americans''. Harper San Francisco. Appendix one "The Roman Ritual of Exorcism" p.459 {{ISBN|0-06-065337-X}}</ref>
The Catholic Church revised the Rite of Exorcism in January 1999, though the traditional Rite of Exorcism in [[Latin]] is allowed as an option. The act of exorcism is considered to be an incredibly dangerous spiritual task. The ritual assumes that possessed persons retain their free will, though the demon may hold control over their physical body, and involves prayers, blessings, and invocations with the use of the document ''[[Of Exorcisms and Certain Supplications]]''. In the modern era, Catholic bishops rarely authorize exorcisms, approaching would-be cases with the presumption that mental or physical illness is more likely.
Solemn exorcisms, according to the [[Canon law (Catholic Church)|Canon law]] of the church, can be exercised only by an ordained priest (or higher prelate), with the express permission of the local bishop, and only after a careful medical examination to exclude the possibility of mental illness,<ref> [http://www.ewtn.com/library/prayer/roman2.txt THE ROMAN RITUAL Translated by PHILIP T. WELLER, S.T.D.]</ref> and in the ritual people cannot in any circumstance be harmed. The ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' (1908) enjoined: "Superstition ought not to be confounded with religion, however much their history may be interwoven, nor magic, however white it may be, with a legitimate religious rite." Things listed in the [[Roman Ritual]] as being indicators of possible demonic possession include: speaking foreign or ancient languages of which the possessed has no prior knowledge; supernatural abilities and strength; knowledge of hidden or remote things which the possessed has no way of knowing; an aversion to anything holy; and profuse [[blasphemy]] and/or [[sacrilege]].
Fr. [[Gabriele Amorth]], who claimed to have performed 160,000 exorcisms, said exorcists have the ability to detect an evil presence. However, he notes that "they are not always right: their 'feelings' must be checked out." In his examples, they are able to detect the events that caused the demon to enter, or are able to discover the evil object that has cursed the individual. He notes that "they are always humble."<ref>Amorth G. (1990) An Exorcist Tells His Story. tns. MacKenzie N. Ignatius Press: San Francisco. pp157-160 {{ISBN|0898707102}}</ref>
=== Eastern Orthodoxy === {{rquote|right|Receive the exorcisms with devotion...Divine exorcisms, borrowed from the Scripture, purify the soul.<ref name="Moine de l'Eglise d'Orient - Exorcism">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=J7abX63aB4IC&pg=PA44&dq=orthodox+exorcism&lr=&cd=16#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism&f=false|title=Orthodox Spirituality: An Outline of the Orthodox Ascetical and Mystical Tradition|quote=St. Cyril of Jerusalem writes: "Receive the exorcisms with devotion...Divine exorcisms, borrowed from the Scripture, purify the soul."|publisher =[[St Vladimir's Seminary Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31}}</ref>|[[St. Cyril of Jerusalem]]}}
In the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], [[demon possession|demonic activity]] is inextricably associated with [[disease]] and [[blight]].<ref name="John Anthony McGuckin">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u4i8jv0b7IkC&pg=PA138&dq=orthodox+exorcism&lr=&cd=20#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism&f=false|quote= In the Orthodox service books the prayers of exorcism attributed to '''''Basil the Great''''' are still in use, for common as well as particular cases of need. In the Latin church the rite of exorcism is now very rarely used, and then only with episcopal permission. The exorcism prayers continue the ancient association of sickness and blight with demonic activity, and the blessings of beasts and fields in the Orthodox service books to this day make a regular pairing of the ideas.|title= The Westminster handbook to patristic theology|publisher =[[Westminster John Knox Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31}}</ref> As a result, exorcisms are quite common, even finding their way in rituals involving the blessing of [[Field (agriculture)|fields]].<ref name="John Anthony McGuckin"/> The exorcism ritual, found in the ''[[Euchologion]]'', is that of [[Basil of Caesarea|St. Basil the Great]].<ref name="John Anthony McGuckin"/> The [[baptism]] liturgy in Eastern Orthodoxy also contains an exorcism ritual.<ref name="Irving Hexham">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=79uJxu1TMFYC&pg=PA49&dq=orthodox+exorcism&lr=&cd=14#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism&f=false|quote=In the Orthodox Church exorcism is practiced prior to baptism.|title= Pocket Dictionary of New Religious Movements |publisher =[[InterVarsity Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31}}</ref><ref name="Moine de l'Eglise d'Orient - Baptism">{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=J7abX63aB4IC&pg=PA44&dq=orthodox+exorcism&lr=&cd=16#v=onepage&q=orthodox%20exorcism&f=false|title=Orthodox Spirituality: An Outline of the Orthodox Ascetical and Mystical Tradition|quote=In the Orthodox rites of Baptism, this liberating action of Christ is expressed in the denial of Satan by the catechumens and in the exorcisms of the priest.|publisher =[[St Vladimir's Seminary Press]]|accessdate = 2007-12-31}}</ref>
=== Lutheranism === The [[Lutheran Church]] traces the practice of exorcism to the Scriptural claim that [[Jesus Christ]] expelled demons with a simple command (Mark 1:23–26; 9:14–29; Luke 11:14–26).<ref name="LCMS-Exorcism"/> The [[Apostle (Christian)|apostles]] continued the practice with the power and in the name of Jesus (Matthew 10:1; Acts 19:11–16).<ref name="LCMS-Exorcism"/> Contrary to some [[Christian denomination|denominations]] of [[Christianity]], Lutheranism affirms that the individual, both the believer and the non-believer, can be plagued by demons, based on several arguments, including the one that "just as a believer, whom Jesus Christ has delivered from sin (Romans 6:18), can still be bound by sin in his life, so he can still be bound by a demon in his life."<ref name="Kaohsiung Lutheran Mission-Exorcism">{{cite web|url = http://johnsmith.asia/can_christians.htm| title = Can a Christian Have a Demon?|publisher = Kaohsiung Lutheran Mission|accessdate = 2009-05-27}}</ref>
After the [[Protestant Reformation]], [[Martin Luther]] abbreviated the Roman ritual used for exorcism.<ref name="Christian Classics Ethereal Library-Exorcism"/> In 1526, the ritual was further abbreviated and the [[Insufflation|exsufflation]] was omitted. This form of the ''Lutheran Ritual for Exorcism'' was incorporated into the majority of the Lutheran service-books and implemented.<ref name="Christian Classics Ethereal Library-Exorcism"/><ref name="Ferber-Lutheran Exorcism">{{cite book |last=Ferber|first=Sarah|title=Demonic possession and exorcism in early modern France|year=2004 |publisher=Routledge|page=38|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DNS5oatndpUC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=exorcism+lutheran&source=bl&ots=Fu9K0BClts&sig=2VDybAx064WNAL03kxu5jm1tr_E&hl=en&ei=NdMcSo7VMZGMNeejtJUP&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#PPA38,M1|accessdate=2009-05-25|isbn=0-415-21265-0}}</ref> According to a Pastoral Handbook of the [[Lutheran Church]], {{quote|In general, satanic possession is nothing other than an action of the devil by which, from God's permission, men are urged to sin, and he occupies their bodies, in order that they might lose eternal salvation. Thus bodily possession is an action by which the devil, from divine permission, possesses both pious and impious men in such a way that he inhabits their bodies not only according to activity, but also according to essence, and torments them, either for the punishment or for the discipline and testing of men, and for the glory of divine justice, mercy, power, and wisdom.<ref name="Christian Classics Ethereal Library-Exorcism"/><ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/>}}
These pastoral manuals warn that often, symptoms such as ecstasy, epileptic seizures, lethargy, insanity, and a frantic state of mind, are the results of natural causes and should not be mistaken for [[demon possession]].<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism">{{cite web|url = http://www.angelfire.com/ny4/djw/lutherantheology.demonpossession.html| title = Quotes and Paraphrases from Lutheran Pastoral Handbooks of the 16th and 17th Centuries on the Topic of Demon Possession|publisher = David Jay Webber|accessdate = 2009-05-27}}</ref> According to the Lutheran Church, primary symptoms that may indicate demon possession and the need of an exorcism include: #The knowledge of secret things, for example, being able to predict the future (Acts 16:16), find lost people or things, or know complex things that one has never learned (e.g., medicine). It is said that fortune-tellers often ask a spirit for help and that this spirit gives them certain powers. In that case, the evil spirit is assisting, not necessarily possessing the person bodily.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> #The knowledge of languages one has never learned. Just as the devil can bind one's tongue (Luke 11:14), it is reported from the early church as well as the time of the Reformation that certain demon-possessed people could speak languages they had never learned.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> #Supernatural strength (Mark 5:2-3), far beyond what they previously had or should have considering their sex and size. Much caution in judging demon possession is required. All of the circumstances and symptoms must be taken into consideration. Insanity should not be confused with possession. On the other hand, possession may be taking place even where these symptoms are absent.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> The Church lists the secondary symptoms of horrible shouting (Mark 5:5), [[blasphemy]] of [[Holy Trinity|God]] and jeering at one's neighbor, deformation of movements (e.g. ferocious movements, facial contortion, immodest laughing, gnashing of teeth, spitting, removing clothes, lacerating self, Mk. 9:20; Lk. 8:27.), inhuman revelry (e.g. when they take food beyond the capability of nature), torment of bodies, unusual injuries of the body and of those nearby, extraordinary motion of bodies (e.g., an elderly man who, being demon-possessed, was able to run as fast as a horse), and forgetfulness of things done.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> Other symptoms include the corruption of reason in man, which make him like an animal, melancholy, the acceleration of death (Mark 9:18 [suicide attempts]), and the presence of other supernatural occurrences.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/>
After these determinations have been made, the Church recommends experienced physicians to determine whether there is a medical explanation for the behaviour of the individual.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> When a true possession is recognized, the poor one is to be committed to the care of a [[Minister (Christianity)|minister of the Church]] who teaches sound doctrine, is of a blameless life, who does nothing for the sake of filthy lucre, but does everything from the soul.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> The pastor is then to diligently inquire what kind of life the possessed one led up to this point and lead him or her through the law to the recognition of his [[sins]].<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> After this admonition or consolation has taken place, the works of a natural physician are to be used, who will cleanse the possessed one from malicious fluids with the appropriate medicines.<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/> The Pastoral Handbook then states: {{quote| *Let ardent prayers be poured forth to God, not only by the ministers of the Church, but also by the whole Church. Let these prayers be conditioned, if the liberation should happen for God's glory and the salvation of the possessed person, for this is an evil of the body. *With the prayers let [[fasting]] be joined, see Matthew 17:21. *[[Alms]] by friends of the possessed person, Tobit 12:8-9. *Let the [[Confession of faith|confession of the Christian faith]] be once required of Him, let him be taught concerning the works of the devil destroyed by Christ, let him be sent back faithfully to this Destroyer of Satan, Jesus Christ, let an exhortation be set up to faith in Christ, to prayers, to [[penitence]].<ref name="Mayes-Lutheran Exorcism"/>}}
===Mennonites=== Many [[Mennonite]] colleges and seminaries include training for the ministry of exorcism. The Mennonite minister and exorcist Dean Hochstetler states that [[Pow-wow (folk magic)|powwowing]], a practice done by some in the [[Pennsylvania Dutch]] community, "brings people under bondage to Satan."<ref name="Kriebel2007">{{cite book|last=Kriebel|first=David W.|title=Powwowing Among the Pennsylvania Dutch: A Traditional Medical Practice in the Modern World|year=2007|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=9780271032139|page=204|quote=Mennonites of the Lancaster Conference "seem to think that it's black magic and related to the devil and just don't think it's very good." Dean Hochstetler, an Indiana Mennonite minister and exorcist raised in an Amish community, agreed with this sentiment, saying, "[[Powwowing]] does one thing well, brings people under bondage to Satan."}}<!--|accessdate=5 May 2014--></ref> On 30 July to 1 August 1987, the "Associated Mennonite Biblical Seminaries, Mennonite Board of Missions (MC) and the Indiana-Michigan Mennonite Conference (MC) sponsored a consultation on 'Bondage and Deliverance'."<ref name="DyckMartin1990">{{cite book|last1=Dyck|first1=Cornelius J.|last2=Martin|first2=Dennis D.|title=The Mennonite encyclopedia: a comprehensive reference work on the Anabaptist-Mennonite movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HiQOAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 May 2014|year=1990|publisher=Mennonite Brethren Pub. House|isbn=9780836131055|quote=The Associated Mennonite Biblical Seminaries, Mennonite Board of Missions (MC), Oaklawn Psychiatric Center (all in Elkhart, Ind.), and the Indiana-Michigan Mennonite Conference (MC) sponsored a consultation on "Bondage and Deliverance," July 30-Aug. 1, 1987.}}</ref>
===Methodism=== The [[British Methodist Church]] holds that the ritual of exorcism involves "the casting out of an objective power of evil which has gained possession of a person."<ref name="The Methodist Church-Exorcism (1)">{{cite book|title=The Methodist Conference - Friday 25th June, 1976 (Preston)|quote=...the casting out of an objective power of evil which has gained possession of a person.|publisher = The Methodist Church of Great Britain|accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref> Moreover, the Methodist Church teaches that "the authority to exorcise has been given to the Church as one of the ways in which Christ's Ministry is continued in the world."<ref name="The Methodist Church-Exorcism (2)">{{cite book|title=The Methodist Conference - Friday 25th June, 1976 (Preston)|quote=...the authority to exorcise has been given to the Church as one of the ways in which Christ's Ministry is continued in the world.|publisher = The Methodist Church of Great Britain|accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref> A [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]] must first consult the District Chair in order to perform an exorcism.<ref name="The Methodist Church-Exorcism (3)">{{cite book|title=The Methodist Conference - Friday 25th June, 1976 (Preston)|quote=The form of any service of healing for those believed to be possessed should be considered in consultation with the ministerial staff of the circuit (or in one-minister circuits with those whom the Chairman of the District suggests).|publisher = The Methodist Church of Great Britain|accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref> The Methodist Church holds that it is of great importance to ensure that the presence and love of Christ is assured to the individual(s) seeking help.<ref name="The Methodist Church-Exorcism (4)">{{cite book|title=The Methodist Conference - Friday 25th June, 1976 (Preston)|quote=Since pastoral guidance is first and foremost concerned to assure the presence and love of Christ, it is important to follow this practice in these cases also.|publisher = The Methodist Church of Great Britain|accessdate =2008-05-23}}</ref> In addition, the ministry of the "Bible, prayer and sacraments" should be extended to these individuals as well.<ref name="The Methodist Church-Exorcism (5)">{{cite book|title=The Methodist Conference - Friday 25th June, 1976 (Preston)|quote=The ministry of bible, prayer and sacraments should be extended to those seeking help. |publisher = The Methodist Church of Great Britain|accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref> A combination of these things has been proven to be effective.<ref name="Westminster Methodist Central Hall-Exorcism">{{cite web|url = http://www.methodist-central-hall.org.uk/sermons/MartinTurnerSermons/ExorcismIn2006.pdf| title = Exorcism in 2006|publisher = Westminster Methodist Central Hall (Rev. Martin Turner)|accessdate = 2009-05-25}}</ref>
For example, in one particular situation, a Roman Catholic woman believed that her house was haunted, and therefore consulted her [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priest]] for assistance. Since he was not available to drive the [[demons]] from the woman's home, she contacted a Methodist pastor, who exorcised the evil spirits from a room, which was believed to be the source of distress in the house, and celebrated [[Holy Communion]] in the same place;<ref name="Westminster Methodist Central Hall-Exorcism"/> following these actions, there was no longer any problem in the house.<ref name="Westminster Methodist Central Hall-Exorcism"/> In another situation, The Reverend Jay Bartlett writes that a young lady who was involved with "drug abuse, self mutilation, severe abuse, mental torment, Satanism, occult activity, communion with demons, and other evils" was exorcised at Mt. Olive Free Methodist Church in [[Dallas]] over a period of seven nights, with "[[anointing oil]], the Word of God (the sword of the Spirit), [[holy water]], the sacred symbols of the cross, the [[blood of Christ]], and consecrated materials [being] utilized to drive out the demons."<ref name="Ford2010">{{cite book|last1=Ford|first1=Christopher |last2=Ford|first2=Nataley|title=Demons, Deliverance and Dissociation|date=31 January 2010|isbn=9781445276359|page=154}}<!--|accessdate=5 May 2014--></ref>
===Oriental Orthodoxy=== In the [[Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church]], priests intervene and perform exorcisms on behalf of those believed to be afflicted by demons or ''[[buda (folk religion)|buda]]''. According to a 2010 [[Pew Research Center]] study, 74% of Christians in Ethiopia claim to have experienced or witnessed an exorcism.<ref name="bbc2010-04-15">{{cite news |title=Ten things we have learnt about Africa |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8620249.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=April 15, 2010 |accessdate=April 15, 2010 |quote="In Ethiopia, 74% of Christians say they have experienced or witnessed the devil or evil spirits being driven out of a person"}}</ref> Demon-possessed persons are brought to a church or prayer meeting.<ref name="geleta">Geleta, Amsalu Tadesse. "[http://www.lausanne.org/all-documents/ethiopian-case-study.html Case Study: Demonization and the Practice of Exorcism in Ethiopian Churches] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100101104543/http://www.lausanne.org/all-documents/ethiopian-case-study.html |date=2010-01-01 }}". Lausanne Committee for World Evangelization, Nairobi, August 2000.</ref> Often, when an ill person has not responded to modern medical treatment, the affliction is attributed to demons.<ref name="geleta" /> Unusual or especially perverse deeds, particularly when performed in public, are symptomatic of a demoniac.<ref name="geleta" /> Superhuman strength – such as breaking one's bindings, as described in the New Testament accounts – along with [[glossolalia]] are observed in the afflicted.<ref name="geleta" /> Amsalu Geleta, in a modern case study, relates elements that are common to Ethiopian Christian exorcisms: <blockquote> It includes singing praise and victory songs, reading from the Scripture, prayer and confronting the spirit in the name of Jesus. Dialogue with the spirit is another important part of the exorcism ceremony. It helps the counselor (exorcist) to know how the spirit was operating in the life of the demoniac. The signs and events mentioned by the spirit are affirmed by the victim after deliverance.<ref name="geleta" /></blockquote>
The exorcism is not always successful, and Geleta notes another instance in which the usual methods were unsuccessful, and the demons apparently left the subject at a later time. In any event, "in all cases the spirit is commanded in no other name than the name of Jesus."<ref name="geleta" />
===Pentecostalism=== In the [[Pentecostal Church]], [[Charismatic Movement]], and other the less formalized sections of Christianity, the exorcism ritual can take many forms and belief structures. The most common of these is the [[Deliverance ministry|deliverance ceremony]]. Deliverance differs from the exorcism ceremony in that the Devil may have gotten a foothold into a person's life rather than gaining complete control . If complete control has been gained, a full-fledged exorcism is necessary. However, a "spirit-filled Christian" cannot be possessed, based on their beliefs. Within this belief structure, the reasons for the devil to get a foothold are usually explained to be some sort of deviation from theological doctrine or because of pre-conversion activities (like dealing with the occult).<ref>Poloma M. (1982) The Charismatic Movement: is there a new Pentecost? p97 {{ISBN|0805797211}}</ref><ref>Cuneo M. (2001) American Exorcism: Expelling Demons in the Land of Plenty. Doubleday: New York. pp.111-128 {{ISBN|0385501765}}</ref>
The traditional method for determining if a person needs a deliverance is done by having someone present who has the gift of discerning of spirits. This is a gift of the Holy Spirit from 1 Corinthians 12 that allows a person to "sense" in some way an evil presence.<ref>Poloma M. (1982) The Charismatic Movement: is there a new Pentecost? p60 {{ISBN|0-8057-9721-1}}</ref> While the initial diagnosis is usually uncontested by the congregation, when many people are endowed with this gift in a single congregation, results may vary.<ref>Cuneo M. (2001) American Exorcism: Expelling Demons in the Land of Plenty. Doubleday: New York. pp.118-119 {{ISBN|0-385-50176-5}}</ref>
==Criticism== Critics of exorcism contend that so-called 'possession' is often, in fact, undiagnosed mental illness and the performance of an exorcism in such cases exacerbates the condition and can even be considered abuse.<ref> [https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/johann-hari/johann-hari-the-devilish-church-practice-of-exorcism-770658.html 'Johann Hari: The devilish church practice of exorcism'] The Independent, 18 Jan. 2008</ref> There have also been cases where exorcists have abused their position for financial gain.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1583812/Priest-made-3m-from-fake-exorcisms.html "Priest 'made £3m from fake exorcisms'"] ''Telegraph'' 3 April 2008</ref>

{{Redirect|Ghunghat|other uses}} [[File:Rajasthan Girl Traditional Dress.jpg|thumb|A Hindu woman with a ghoonghat veil]] A '''ghoonghat''' (''ghunghat'', ''ghunghta'', ''ghumta'', ''odhni'', ''laaj'', ''chunari'', ''jhund'') is a [[veil]] or [[headscarf]] worn by some married Hindu, and Jain women to cover their head, and often their face. Generally ''aanchal'' or ''pallu'', the loose end of a [[sari]] is pulled over the head and face to act as a ghunghat. A ''[[dupatta]]'' (long scarf) is also commonly used as a ghungat. Today, facial veiling by Hindu women as part of everyday attire is now mostly limited to the Hindi-speaking areas of India.<ref>Raj Mohini Sethi (2011) "Socio-economic Profile of Rural India (series II).", p.111</ref><ref>IHDS 2004–5 data "Gender and Family Dynamics.", p.153</ref>
Facial veiling is not sanctioned in Hinduism, Jainism, and Buddhism but some sections of the society from the 1st century B.C. advocated the use of the veil for married women, which came to be known as ghoonghat.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.174</ref> It has been both romanticized and criticized in religious and folk literature.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.171</ref>
==Etymology== The word ''ghoongat'', ''ghunghat'' or ''ghunghta'' is derived from ''Avagunthana'' ([[Sanskrit]]: अवगुण्ठन) meaning ''veil'', ''hiding'' and ''cloak'' and ''Oguntheti'' ([[Pali]]: ओगुन्थेति) ''to cover'', ''veil over'' and ''hide''.<ref>http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?tinput=avaguNThana&script=&direction=SE&link=yes</ref><ref>Ambalaṅgoḍa Polvattē Buddhadatta, A. P. (1957) "Concise Pāli-English Dictionary.", p.69</ref>
==History== [[File:22 A standing woman in floral patterned white sari, a peacock-plume patterned cloak. 18 centiry, San Diego Museum of Art.jpg|thumb| Women in veiling, Rajput miniature painting.]]
The ''ghoongat'', ''ghunghat'' or ''ghunghta'' veil evolved from ancient ''Avagunthana'' in ([[Sanskrit]]: अवगुण्ठन) ''veil'', ''hiding'' and ''cloak''.<ref>http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?tinput=avaguNThana&script=&direction=SE&link=yes</ref> Early Sanskrit literature has a wide vocabulary of terms for the veils used by women, such as ''avagunthana'' meaning cloak-veil, ''uttariya'' meaning shoulder-veil, ''mukha-pata'' meaning face-veil, and ''sirovas-tra'' meaning head-veil.<ref>Govind Sadashiv Ghurye (1951) "Indian Costume.", p.236</ref><ref>Ramesh Prasad Mohapatra (1992) "Fashion Styles of Ancient India: A Study of Kalinga from Earliest Times to Sixteenth Century AD", p.24</ref>
In [[Valmiki]]'s ''[[Ramayana]]'' dated between the 5th century BCE to the first century BCE, Prince [[Rama]] asks his wife [[Sita]] to unveil herself so that the gathered citizens of Ayodhya can take a look at them before they go in exile to the forest; there is no mention of [[Sita]] veiling herself again after this incident.<ref>Anjani Kant (1951) "Women and the Law.", p.43</ref> At the end of the epic, hearing the news of Ravana's death, his queens giving up to lamentations rush outside without their ''Avagunthana'', in which chief queen [[Mandodari]] surrounding his corpse says "''Why do you not get angry, beholding me, having put off my veil, walk out on foot by the city gate? Do you behold your wives who have thrown off their veils. Why are you not angry seeing them all come out of the city?''"<ref name="Valmiki Ramanaya, chapter 111"> Valmiki Ramanaya, chapter 111 - stanza 6-111-63 and 6-111-64</ref> Thus, it is notable that royal women avoided public gaze and veiling was expected to be worn only by married women.<ref>Anjani Kant (1951) "Women and the Law.", p.43</ref>
[[Śūdraka]], the author of [[Mṛcchakatika]] set in the fifth century BC, said that the ''Avagaunthaha'' was not used by women everyday and at every time. He said that a married lady was expected to put on a veil while moving in the public. This may indicate that it was not necessary for unmarried females to put on a veil.<ref>Sulochana Ayyar (1987) "Costumes and Ornaments as Depicted in the Sculptures of Gwalior Museum.", p.152</ref>
In [[Mṛcchakatika]] written in 3rd century BCE, courtesan [[Vasantasena]]'s mother, having received ornaments for her daughter from a wealthy suitor to keep her as his mistress, she sends Vasantasena with her maid, asks her to go in the carriage bedecked with ornaments and to put on her ''avagunthana'' veil. This instruction is taken to signify that a [[courtesan]] who has accepted a suitor, had to use a veil in public similar to married women.<ref>Govind Sadashiv Ghurye (1951) "Indian Costume.", p.236</ref> At the end of the play when Vasanthasena is legally wedded, she receives the title "''Vadhūśabda''" meaning "''title of a bride''" simultaneously with the veil "''vasantasenām avagunthya''" meaning "''a token of honorable marriage''".<ref>Laurie Patton (1961) "Jewels of Authority: Women and Textual Tradition in Hindu India.", p.81</ref> In the same literature, courtesans' maid servant Madanika marries her lover Sarvilaka, a thief who changes his ways. Her new husband says to her that she has achieved what is difficult to acquire: "''Vadhūśabda avagunthanam''" meaning "''the title and veil of a bride''".<ref>Laurie Patton (1961) "Jewels of Authority: Women and Textual Tradition in Hindu India.", p.81</ref>
In the ''Pratimānātaka'', a play by [[Bhāsa]] (3 - 4 CE) describes in context of the ''Avagunthana'' cloak-veil that "''ladies may be seen without any blame [for the parties concerned] in a religious session, in marriage festivities, during a calamity and in a forest''".<ref>Govind Sadashiv Ghurye (1951) "Indian Costume.", p.236</ref> The same sentiment is more generically expressed in ''[[Nagananda|Nāgānanda]]'' and ''[[Priyadarsika|Priyadarśikā]]'' by [[Harsha]], where maidens were expected to wear no veil; it was donned only after the marriage.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization, p.170</ref> Later, the veil was referred to by the same term, ''avagunthana'', in ''[[Shishupala Vadha|Śiśupālavadha]]'' and the ''[[Dashakumaracharita]]''.<ref>Sulochana Ayyar (1987) "Costumes and Ornaments as Depicted in the Sculptures of Gwalior Museum.", p.152</ref> According to commentator Sankara, the ladies of [[Thanesar|Sthanvisvara]] used to go about covering their faces with a veil.<ref>Govind Sadashiv Ghurye (1951) "Indian Costume.", p.239</ref>
[[File:हिन्दू विवाह सम्प्रदाय 5 - जयपुर, भारत.JPG|thumb|Bride in ghoonghat during ''Muh Dikhai'' ceremony, Rajasthan, India.]]
In Buddhist [[Mahayana]] literature, [[Lalitavistara Sūtra]] written in the 3rd century CE, young bride [[Yasodharā]] objected to observe veiling (oguntheti/oguṇthikā) in front of respected elders. This was taken to be a sign of immodesty and willfulness, as people criticized her and gossiped.<ref>Betty Kelen 1967 "Gautama Buddha: In Life and Legend" chapter 1, pp. 7 and 8</ref> When she became aware of this, Yasodharā came before the assembled court and defended herself in a long statement: "Those whose thoughts have no cover, no shame or decorum or any virtue, those who gossip, may cover themselves with a thousand garments, yet they walk the earth naked. But those who veil their minds, control their senses, and have no thought for any other except their husband, why should they veil their faces?" Yasodharā's parents-in-law were delighted with their daughter-in-law's proud statement and gave her two white garments covered with jewels.<ref>Betty Kelen 1967 "Gautama Buddha: In Life and Legend" chapter 1, pp. 7 and 8</ref>
The [[Lalitavistara Sūtra]] reflects changing times around the 3rd century CE and Buddhists' attempt to counter this growing practice, as there is no mention of this entire incident in early Buddhist [[Theravada Buddhism|Theravada]] literature.<ref>Betty Kelen 1967 "Gautama Buddha: In Life and Legend" chapter 1, pp. 7 and 8</ref><ref>Rohini Chowdhury 2011 "Gautama Buddha: The Lord of Wisdom" chapter 1, page 9.</ref>
In ''[[Shakuntala (play)|Abhijñānaśākuntalam]]'' by [[Kālidāsa]], written between the 3rd and 4th century CE, when the heroine arrives at King [[Dushyanta#King_Dushyant|Duhsanta]]'s palace, seeking to take up her wifely status, the king first remarks "''Kā svid avagunthanavati''" meaning "''who is this veiled one?''" and immediately forbears to look at her, with the words "Anirvarnaniyam parakalatram" meaning "''The wife of another is not to be inspected.''"<ref>Laurie Patton (1961) "Jewels of Authority: Women and Textual Tradition in Hindu India.", p.81</ref> This largely indicates that ''Avagunthana'' was a sign of a respectable married woman, and was a married woman's raiment.<ref>Laurie Patton (1961) "Jewels of Authority: Women and Textual Tradition in Hindu India.", p.81</ref>
===Medieval period=== In ''[[Kathasaritsagara|Kathāsaritsāgara]]'' written in the 11th century AD, heroine in the story ''Ratnaprabhā'' protesting: "''I consider that the strict seclusion of women is a folly produced by jealousy. It is of no use whatsoever. Women of good character are guarded only by their own virtue and nothing else.''"<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.173</ref> Rational opposition against veiling and seclusion from spirited ladies resulted in the system not becoming popular for several centuries.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.171</ref> However, it is notable that some section of society from the 1st century B.C. advocated the use of the veil for married women. There is no proof that a large section of society observed ''strict'' veiling until the [[medieval]] period.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.174</ref>
Under the [[Islamic]] [[Mughal Empire]], various aspects of veiling and seclusion of women was adopted, such as the concept of [[Purdah]] and [[Zenana]], partly as an additional protection for women.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.175</ref> [[Purdah]] became common in the 15th and 16th century, as both ''Vidyāpati'' and ''Chaitanya'' mention it.<ref>Anant Sadashiv Altekar (1959) "The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization.", p.175</ref> [[Sikhism]] was highly critical of [[purdah]]; [[Guru Amar Das]] condemned it and rejected seclusion and veiling of women, which saw decline of [[purdah]] among most classes during this period.
[[File:हिन्दू विवाह सम्प्रदाय - जयपुर, भारत.jpg|thumb|Bride with full veiling during wedding ceremony]]
===Significance=== In ghoonghat practice, facial veiling observed by married women is known as ''Laaj'' ([[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]]: लज्जा, Lajja - ''modesty'', ''honor'', ''shame''). In veiling practice, it literally means "''To keep (one's) modesty, shame and honor''". Earliest attested word ''Laaj'' in context of veiling is found in [[Valmiki]]'s ''Ramayana'' as ''lajjaavaguNThanaan'' describing Mandodari.<ref name="Valmiki Ramanaya, chapter 111"> Valmiki Ramanaya, chapter 111 - stanza 6-111-63 and 6-111-64</ref> However, it is unclear whether it refers to facial veiling.<ref>Anjani Kant (1951) "Women and the Law.", p.43</ref>
During a marriage ceremony, the bride wears a veil given by her parents. Later, during the ceremony the bride's mother-in-law covers her face with ghoonghat; she therefore simultaneously wears the veil given by her parents and that from her in-laws, symbolizing her passing from the protection of one's household to another.<ref>Emma Tarlo 1996 "Clothing Matters: Dress and Identity in India", p.177</ref>
[[Hindu_wedding|Muh Dikhai]] ([[Devanagari script|Devanagari]]: मूह दिखाई, first gaze) is a post-wedding ceremony, where the bride is formally introduced to the groom's relatives and extended family. The ceremony takes place once the bride arrives in her new home; each family member lifts her veil, looks at the bride and gives her a welcoming gift. She receives ''Shagun'' from her mother-in-law, which is typically jewelry, clothing and silverware. After this ceremony the bride observes full veiling for the next few months or until her parents-in-law advise her to unveil.<ref>Doranne Jacobson, Susan Snow Wadley 1999 "Women in India: two perspectives", p.195</ref>
===Post-1900s=== During the early 1900s, women of royal and aristocratic class were first to abandon strict veiling in public. However, the head was loosely veiled due to sensitivity towards the custom during changing times.<ref>Laurie Patton (2004) "Maharanis: The Lives and Times of Three Generations of Indian Princesses.", p.81</ref> The other classes soon followed; it lingered on in some parts of India until well after the 1940s. Facial veiling has gradually declined, and is mostly limited to parts of Hindi-speaking areas today.<ref>Raj Mohini Sethi (2011) "Socio-economic Profile of Rural India (series II).", p.111</ref> In ghungat, a woman will veil her face from all men to whom she's related by marriage and who are senior to her husband. This would include, for example, her husband's father, elder brother and uncles. The effect of ghungat is to limit a young woman's interaction with older men.<ref>{{cite book|last=Guindi|first=Fadwa El|title=Veil: modesty, privacy and resistance|year=2003|publisher=Berg|location=Oxford [u.a.]|isbn=1859739296|pages=109-111|edition=Repr.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Nevile|first=Pran|title=Lahore: a sentimental journey|year=2006|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New Delhi, India|isbn=0143061976|pages=77}}</ref>
In 2004, the India Human Development Survey (IHDS) found that 55% of women in India practice some form of ghoonghat, majority of them in Hindi-speaking states.<ref>IHDS 2004–5 data "Gender and Family Dynamics.", p.153</ref> The survey found that some women may cover their face fully but for others, partial covering of the face is more a nod to propriety than a large impediment.<ref>IHDS 2004–5 data "Gender and Family Dynamics.", p.153</ref>
===Gallery=== <gallery> File:हिन्दू विवाह सम्प्रदाय 4 - जयपुर, भारत.JPG|Bride in veiling during Muh Dikhai ceremony. File:Ghoomar.jpg|Women in veil performing folk dance at wedding. File:Rajput Woman performing Ghoomar 01.jpg|Women performing folk dance in ghoonghat. </gallery>

{{coord|43|06|41.27|N|70|47|40.04|W|type:city_scale:10000|display=title}} [[File:Inn at Green Acre Baha'i School 03.jpg|thumb|right|260px|The Inn at [[Green Acre]], in [[Eliot, Maine]].]] {{Bahá'í sidebar}}
'''Green Acre Bahá'í School''' is one of three leading institutions owned by the [[Bahá'í Faith in the United States|National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States]]. The name of the site has had various versions of "Green Acre" since before its founding in 1894 by Sarah Farmer and is a conference facility in [[Eliot, Maine]], in the [[United States]]. It had a prolonged process of progress and challenge while run by Farmer until about 1913 when she was indisposed after converting to the [[Bahá'í Faith]] in 1900. [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, visited there during his travels in the West in 1912. Farmer died in 1916 and thereafter it had evolved into the quintessential [[Bahá'í school]] directly inspiring [[Louhelen Bahá'í School]] and [[Bosch Bahá'í School]], the other two of the three schools owned by the national assembly, and today serves as a leading institution of the religion in America. It hosted diverse programs of study, presenters, and been a focus for dealing with [[racism in the United States]] through being a significant venue for [[Race Amity Convention]]s (later renamed Race Unity Day meetings) and less than a century later the [[Black Men's Gathering]]s and further events.
==Origin== The [[Piscataqua River]] by which Green Acre Bahá'í school stands was named from [[Abenaki]] Native Americans of the [[Wabanaki Confederacy]] describing where a river separates into several parts - "a place where boats and canoes ascending the river together from its mouth were compelled to separate according to their several destinations."<ref>{{cite web | author=J. Dennis Robinson | title =The Meaning of Piscataqua | website =SearchostNH.com | date =2005 | url =http://www.seacoastnh.com/Places-and-Events/NH-History/the-meaning-of-piscataqua/?showall=1 | accessdate = August 7, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150807135251/http://www.seacoastnh.com/Places-and-Events/NH-History/the-meaning-of-piscataqua/?showall=1 | archivedate = August 7, 2015}}</ref> The town of Eliot was founded 1810 from [[Kittery, Maine]] which itself was founded in the 1600s.<ref>{{cite book|author=Russell M. Lawson|title=The Piscataqua Valley in the Age of Sail: A Brief History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0G0dNCCVUegC&pg=PA18|year=2007|publisher=The History Press|isbn=978-1-59629-219-2|page=18}}</ref> By the mid 1800s the area served as a shipyard including launching the [[USS Nightingale (1851)|USS Nightingale]] in 1851.<ref>{{cite web| title =Eliot History Time Line| work =| publisher =Old Berwick Historical Society| date =March 16, 2001| url =http://www.oldberwick.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=417:eliot-time-line&catid=53:historical-events&Itemid=72| accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Ingersoll>{{cite book | last = Ingersoll | first =Anna Josephine | title =Greenacre on the Piscataqua | publisher =Alliance Publishing Co | year =October 1900 | pages = | url =https://archive.org/details/greenacreonpisca00inge }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Sullivan | first =Jacqueline Ballou | title =The House on Goodwin Road | publisher =eliothistoricalsociety.org | url =http://www.eliothistoricalsociety.org/eliot-memory-project/miscellaneous-memories/the-house-on-goodwin-road/ | accessdate = August 1, 2015}}</ref> At the time of the founding of the school there were some 1,400 people in Eliot and the town has grown in recent years to near 7,000 today.<ref name=Robinson2013>{{cite web | title =Going Crazy in Portsmouth |author= J. Dennis Robinson | website =SeascostNH.com | date =2013 | url =http://www.seacoastnh.com/History/As-I-Please/going-crazy-in-portsmouth/?showall=1 | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
===The Farmers=== Sarah Farmer's mother, Hannah Tobey Farmer (1823–1891) was raised Methodist.<ref name=Schmidt>{{cite book|author=Leigh Eric Schmidt|title=Restless Souls: The Making of American Spirituality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wbk80IOIgzEC|date=6 August 2012|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-95411-3}}</ref>{{rp|p.191}} Her father, [[Moses G. Farmer|Moses Gerrish Farmer]] (1820–1893) a Dartmouth graduate in 1844,<ref name=DEM2014>{{cite journal | author=Lee Michaelides |editor=Karen Endicott | title =Inventions: Electric Light - Inventor: Moses Farmer, Class of 1844 | journal = Dartmouth Engineering Magazine | volume =10 | issue =2 | page =32 | date = Fall 2014 | url =http://engineering.dartmouth.edu/magazine/inventions-electric-light/ | accessdate =August 11, 2015}}</ref> had success in the new field of [[History of electrical engineering#19th century developments|electrical engineering]] and [[Electrical telegraph|telegraph]] work and was a heartfelt Christian,<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.192}} though he has also been called a Spiritualist<ref name=DEM2014/> and Transcendentalist.<ref name=Robinson2013/> Moses and Hannah also married in 1844<ref name=FindingAid>{{cite web | title =Finding Aid for the Moses G. Farmer Papers, 1830–1893 | publisher =Online Archives of California | date =2002 | url =http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt896nb4nb/entire_text/ | accessdate = July 27, 2015}}</ref> and Sarah was born 1847.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.186}} It is said that the Farmer's home, before they lived in Eliot, was part of the [[Underground railroad]].<ref name=Atkinson1990>{{cite web | author=Anne Gordon Atkinson | title =Introduction to Green Acre Bahá'í School | website =Bahai-Library.com | date =1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/atkinson_history_green_acre | accessdate = August 2, 2015 }}</ref>
It is unclear when the land in Eliot came to be owned by the Farmer family. However, they lived in a variety of places in New England until, after 1880, when the family moved to Eliot and Moses retired.<ref name=FindingAid/> The home they built in Eliot was called Bittersweat, or Bittersweet-in-the-Fields.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.7,163}}</small> Hannah established a memorial non-segregated service called "Rosemary" as a retreat for unwed or poor mothers and working women<ref name=Perry2012>{{cite book|title=Green Acre on the Piscataqua|url=http://www.bahaibookstore.com/Green-Acre-on-the-Piscataqua-P6883.aspx|year=2012|edition=3rd|orig-year=1991|publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust |isbn=978-0-87743-364-4 |author1= Anne Gordon Perry | author2= Rosanne Adams-Junkins| author3= Robert Atkinson| author4= Richard Grover| author5= Diane Iverson| author6= Robert H Stockman| author7= Burton W.F. Trafton Jr.}}</ref>{{rp|p.7}} in Eliot where, for a donation of $7 ($181 in 2014,)<ref name=inflation>{{cite web |title=The Inflation Calculator |publisher=S. Morgan Friedman |date=2015 |url=http://www.westegg.com/inflation/ |accessdate=August 28, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5QVXNUZmW?url=http://www.westegg.com/inflation/ |archivedate=July 21, 2007 |df= }}</ref> families would have a two-week vacation, up to 40 at a time in 1888.<ref>{{cite book|author=Everett Schermerhorn Stackpole|title=Old Kittery and Her Families|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NMV8ijlqeA0C&pg=PA238|year=1903|publisher=Press of Lewiston journal Company|pages=238–241}}</ref> In 1887 Sarah re-animated the Eliot Library Association and set a number of meetings with speakers while also serving as secretary and helping build a list of patrons of the library of some 700 people.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p8}} Singer [[Emma Cecilia Thursby]] recalled her first visit to what was called "Greenacre" was in 1889.<ref>{{cite web| title =Guide to the Emma Thursby Papers| publisher =New-York Historical Society| year =2011| url = http://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/nyhs/thursby/thursby.html | accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref> Greenacre is and was situated on a bluff overlooking the river which is a mile wide.<ref name=NYT1897>{{cite news | title =Greenacre-on-the-Piscataqua |author=R. Osgood Mason | newspaper =New York Times | location =New York, New York | page = | date =Sep 19, 1897 | url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/09/19/102062495.pdf | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A group of investors signed a contract to set up a hotel at the cite in 1890 initially called the Eliot Hotel or Inn.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.8}} In 1891 there were paying customers staying at the Inn.<ref>{{cite news | title =Winsome Greenacres | newspaper = Boston Evening Transcript | location = Boston, Massachusetts | page =7 | date = Aug 29, 1891 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=18910829&id=5Hs-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=GFoMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4967,4412231&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015}}</ref> Farmer had an originating idea about a spiritual theme for the development of the property in June 1892<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.311–2}}</small> and then journeyed with her father to the [[Chicago Columbian Exposition]] in late 1892 where she met with [[Swedenborgian]] [[Charles Bonney]], the "visionary" behind the [[World's Parliament of Religions]],<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.192}} and gained encouragement for her vision for a center of learning for spiritual teachers<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.17,192}}</small> - an idea blessed by family friends Arthur Wesley Down and [[John Greenleaf Whittier]].<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.80}} Her father died that spring, 1893, and she had to leave before the Parliament took place.<ref>{{cite news | title =Passsed away | newspaper =Logansport Pharos-Tribune | location =Logansport, Indiana | pages =1 | date =26 May 1893 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3009760/obit_of_moses_g_farmer_father_of/ | accessdate = August 14, 2015}}</ref> She took a brief trip to Norway with [[Sara Chapman Bull]] in her grief,<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.12}} and she made it back to the Parliament only in October 1893 after it was over.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.192}} Farmer made what she recorded in her diary as a "solemn vow" to building the school for spiritual teachers on 4 February 1894.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.312}} However, by about 1894 the hotel was called a failure and was boarded up when Farmer approached the investors with the plan to use Greenacre as a place to host lectures on religion.<ref name=Menon2>{{cite web |author=Jonathan Menon | title =The Battles of Sarah J. Farmer | website =239days.com | date =August 22, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/22/battles-sarah-j-farmer/ | accessdate =July 28, 2015}}</ref> Farmer proposed to her investors to use the closed Inn.<ref name=Menon2/> By 1897 it was capable of housing 75 or more guests and had a number of cottages around the property with a grassy plain that sometimes hosted a tent camp.<ref name=NYT1897/>
===Sarah Farmer's inauguration of Greenacre=== Following the enthusiasm of the Parliament, Farmer set up the beginnings of using the Greenacre Inn as a summer center of cross-religion gatherings and cultural development. She had success attracting support from Bostonian businessmen, wives of businessmen and politicians, most especially [[Phoebe Hearst]].<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.193}} The work was inaugurated in 1894<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.27,193–4}}</small><ref name="NSA1">{{cite web| title =The Sarah Farmer Inn| work =| publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States| year =2012| url =http://www.greenacre.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=9&Itemid=5| accessdate = November 1, 2013 }}</ref> with her words "The spirit of criticism will be absolutely laid down - if it comes in it will be gently laid aside; each will contribute his best and listen sympathetically to those who present different ideals. The comparison will be made by the audience, not by the teachers."<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.193–4}}</small> The early collection of religious interests was wide - Farmer participated with Spiritualist trance-speakers who appeared to channel her father so convincingly the family dog responded, a fact [[William James]] took note of.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.189}}[[File:Vivekananda Image August 1894.jpg|thumb|right|[[Swami Vivekananda|Vivekananda]] at Greenacre (August 1894)]]
One of the first such promulgators of spiritual insight there was Carl H. A. Bjerregaard where he would frequent through at least 1896.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.25–30}}</small> [[Swami Vivekananda]], a prominent Hindu monk serving in interfaith awareness efforts and spent nearly two months there in the summer of 1894.<ref>{{cite web| last =Vivekananda| first =| authorlink =Vivekananda| title =Letters written between August and December 1894| work =| publisher =Frank Parlato| year =1894| url =http://www.vivekananda.net/knownletters/1894Aug_Dec.html| accessdate =November 1, 2013| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131014115227/http://www.vivekananda.net/knownletters/1894Aug_Dec.html| archivedate =October 14, 2013| df =}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| title =Artifacts of Dedanta History| journal =Sri Sarada Society Newsletter| volume =5| issue =2| page =4| publisher =Srisarada.org| date =Fall 1999| url =http://0308b31.netsolhost.com/notes/collection.pdf| accessdate =November 1, 2013| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131102234750/http://0308b31.netsolhost.com/notes/collection.pdf| archivedate =November 2, 2013| df =}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author = Vivekananda |authorlink = Vivekananda |title = Letters written between August and December 1894 |publisher = Frank Parlato |year = 1894 |url = http://www.vivekananda.net/knownletters/1894Aug_Dec.html |accessdate = August 28, 2015 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131014115227/http://www.vivekananda.net/knownletters/1894Aug_Dec.html |archivedate = October 14, 2013 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title =Artifacts of Dedanta History | journal =Sri Sarada Society Newsletter | volume =5| issue =2 | page =4 | publisher =Srisarada.org | date =Fall 1999 | url =http://0308b31.netsolhost.com/notes/collection.pdf | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131102234750/http://0308b31.netsolhost.com/notes/collection.pdf | archivedate=November 2, 2013 | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> His words were printed in the short lived ''The Greenacre Voice'' established with the school-and-conference center<ref name=RichardsonOC>{{cite journal | last = Richardson | first =Robert P. | title =The Rise and Fall of the Parliament of Religions at Greenacre | journal =The Open Court | volume = XLVI | issue =3 | pages = 128–166 | date = March 1931 | url =https://archive.org/stream/opencourt_mar1931caru#page/n11/mode/2up/ | accessdate = Oct 22, 2013}}</ref> running at least to 1897.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.307}} A review appeared in the local [[Boston Evening Transcript]].<ref>{{cite news | title =School and College - Summer lectures at Greenacre | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =3 | date =Jul 7, 1894 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=18940707&id=eEVfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jVQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4978,383755&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
[[File:Swami Vivekananda in Green Acre August 1894.jpg|thumb|left|[[Swami Vivekananda]] and Sarah Farmer at Green Acre (August 1894)]] A short list of presentations was published in the newspaper even as far away as Chicago also featured academic scholars as well as priests presenting on religions:<ref>{{cite news | title =Life in Boston | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =10 | date =14 Jul 1894 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2892652/greenacre_inauguration_announced_among/ | accessdate = July 27, 2015}}</ref> Professor Ernst Fenollosa, Boston Museum of Fine Arts - "The Relation of Religion to Art"; Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale, "Sociology"; Rev. Dr. William Alger, "Universal Religion"; Edwin Meade, "Immanuel Kant"; Professor Thomas C. Wild, "Union for Practical Progress"; [[Franklin Benjamin Sanborn|Frank B Sanborn]], "The Humane treatment of Mental and Spiritual Aberrations"; Margaret B. Peeke from Sandusky Ohio, "The Soul in its search after God"; and Abby Morton Diaz, "The Work of humanity for humanity" were among the "well known" presenters but the distinction of the summer school was of lecturers who were younger<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.197}} and less well known that those of the earlier [[Concord School of Philosophy]] maintained by the Transcendentalists previously which closed about 1887<ref>{{cite book | last =Hodder | first =Alan D. | title =Thoreau's Ecstatic Witness | publisher =Yale University Press | year =2001 | pages =19 | url =http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/pdf/0300089597.pdf | isbn =0-300-08959-7 }}</ref> and less about philosophy than of comparative study initially.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.197}} The sessions were positively reviewed.<ref>{{cite news | title =The most interesting summer resort ... | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =10 | date =25 Aug 1894 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343704/1894_aug_25_green_acre_by_lilian_whiting/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Sanborn would soon be among the leaders operating at Greenacre. Professor Lewis G. Janes was there giving talks on "Darwin and Spencer", "Social Tendencies under Evolution" and "Life as a Fine Art"<ref>{{cite news | title =Professor Lewis G. Janes, of the Adelphi ... | newspaper =New-York Tribune | location =New York, New York | page =20 | date = July 22, 1894 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1894-07-22/ed-1/seq-20.pdf | accessdate = July 27, 2015 }}</ref> and would also soon take a leading role in developments as well. There was also something of a windstorm that year.<ref>{{cite news | title =Tents blown over at Green Acre | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =9 Aug 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343668/1901_aug_09_tents_blown_over_at_green/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> The "school" had a winter session in Cambridge with several repeat appearances hosted by [[Sara Chapman Bull]].<ref>{{cite news | title =Mrs. Ole Bull and her friend ... | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =14 | date =1 Dec 1894 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2892908/mrs_ole_bull_and_sarah_farmer_talks_in/ | accessdate = July 27, 2015}}</ref> Indeed, these winter sessions continued some years and came to be called the ''Cambridge Conferences'' directed by Janes.<ref name=West1902>{{cite book|title=Lewis G. Janes: Philosopher, Patriot, Lover of Man|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KLg-N5HU-xgC&pg=PA204|year=1902|publisher=James H. West|pages=24, 43, 204}}</ref>
===1895 to 1899=== An 1895 address book of Farmer's revealed she had contact information on a number of leaders of thought and religion in America.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.187–8}}</small> That summer among those that met at the conference center were evolutionists,<ref>{{cite news | title =The Greenacre conference of evolutionists ... | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =11 | date =15 Jun 1895 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2447537/greenacre_conference/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> and Farmer invited Lewis Janes to assist with the program development.<ref>{{cite news | title =Joys at Greenacre | newspaper =The Olean Democrat | location =Olean, New York | page =4 | date =21 Jun 1895 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/658843/1895_june_21_joys_at_greenacre_summer/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Janes was a student of [[Herbert Spencer]].<ref name=West1902/> An engine inventor also presented.<ref>{{cite news | title =Great claims made for Keely Motor | newspaper = Chicago Daily Tribune | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =2 | date =15 Nov 1895 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2896763/o_m_badcock_on_engineering_also_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> The conference grew to the point the Inn itself was too small and a tent camp arose as well as buildings to provide shelter from rain or sun were added.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.26}}<ref name=RichardsonOC/>
In 1896 Sanborn organized an "Emerson Day" (after [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]]) and it continued for more than a decade.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.199}} That year a formal reunion of the [[Concord School of Philosophy]] was also held. In addition to the talks on art, actual musical concerts, painters, sculptors, poets began to make appearances at Greenacre.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.201–2}}</small><ref>* {{cite news | title =Concert at Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =20 Jul 1899 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296648/greenacre_musical_program/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Concert at Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =20 Jul 1899 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296648/greenacre_musical_program/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Strong calls for peace against war from the conference got printed in the ''Boston Evening Transcript''.<ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre resumes | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =6 | date = Jul 3, 1897 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=18970703&id=too-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=6FkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4751,255005&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
The "Monsalvat School for the Comparative Study of Religion", a progressive or liberal development seen against conservative religious experience, was established formally in 1896 as an institution hosted at Greenacre and the first director was Lewis Janes.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.195–6}}</small><ref>{{cite journal | title =Comparative Religion Notes | journal =The Biblical World | volume =8 | issue =2 | pages =166–169 | date =Aug 1896 | jstor =3140267 | doi=10.1086/471931 }}</ref> ''Monsalvat'' was named after the sacred mountain in Wagner's [[Parsifal]] where the [[Holy Grail]] was kept,<ref name=Menon1>{{cite web | author=Jonathan Menon | title = Sarah J. Farmer: One of America's Great Religious Innovators | website =239days.com | date =August 23, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/23/sarah-j-farmer-american-religious-innovator/ | accessdate =July 28, 2015 }}</ref> though it is most often spelled ''Montsalvat''. However, Farmer and Janes differed often - Janes wanted academic credentials among his speakers and a business-like plan for the economic solvency of the work by charging everyone rather than trusting on contributions. They had serious difficulty even agreeing on what they were talking about - "This difference of understanding could never have occurred between two men accustomed to business methods," Janes wrote in 1899.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.196}} Farmer framed the school as a place for encounter between religious leaders for "a fuller realization" of unity among religions, and relied on generosity and enthusiasm to overcome the challenges of economy.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.197}} Nevertheless, the school and Greenacre continue to operate and was noted in newspapers.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Dr. James Brooklyn Work | newspaper = The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =7 | date =1 Nov 1896 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528708/monsalvat_comparative_religions_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title ="Greenacre" is the unique congress ... | newspaper =The Postville Review | location =Postville, Iowa | page =1 | date =13 August 1897 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528712/monsalvat_school_on_comparative/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The Monsalvat School | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =9 | date =3 Jul 1898 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528702/prospectus_outline_greenacre_program/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The Monsalvat School of Comparative Religion | newspaper =Kansas City Journal | location =Kansas City, Missouri | page =4 | date =10 Jul 1898 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528716/monsalvat_school_of_comparative/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Fourth annual session | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =4 | date =18 Jun 1899 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528720/monsalvat_comparative_religion_school/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The Greenacre Lectures | newspaper = Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =7 | date =Sep 4, 1897 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=18970904&id=yfQzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6iIIAAAAIBAJ&pg=6811,391403&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
[[File:Sarah J. Farmer as she was in 1897.jpeg|thumb|Sarah J. Farmer, published in the ''New York Times'', Sept. 19, 1897]][[File:Srimath Anagarika Dharmapala (1864-1933).jpg|left|upright|thumb|Srimath Anagarika Dharmapala in his middle thirties]] The August 1897 season opened with the new lecture hall the "Eirenion", ("place of peace",)<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.16}} and Sarah Farmer and Greenacre made the [[New York Times]].<ref name=NYT1897/> A book was circulated in Japan about it too.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.16}} Prominent Buddhist monk [[Anagarika Dharmapala]] stayed at Greenacre where he worked on practices himself and offered classes and talks on specific meditational disciplines as well as quotes on the teachings of the Buddha.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.168–170,200}}</small><ref>{{cite book|author=Thomas A. Tweed|title=The American Encounter with Buddhism, 1844–1912: Victorian Culture and the Limits of Dissent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9AjICQAAQBAJ|date=12 October 2005|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=978-0-8078-7615-2|pages=88, 221}}</ref> He was enthusiastic about the kind of interfaith coming together process of Greenacre. Unitarian Alfred W. Martin closed the 1897 season with a talk "Universal Religion and the World's Religions", the theme of which became his life's work.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.136–7}}</small> Electrical engineers met at the conference center at least in 1897<ref>* {{cite book|title=Electrical Engineer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qehQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA513|accessdate=20 September 2013|year=1897|publisher=Electrical Engineer|page=513}}</ref> as the fiftieth anniversary of the invention of the electric tolley car.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.16}}
The 1898 session on the Monsalvat school listed a variety of people including Janes himself on "Relation of Science to Religious Thought", [[Swami Abhedananda]] on "Vedanta philosophy and Religions of India", "Hebrew Prophets" by Prof. Nathaniel Schmidt, "Literature, Ethics and Philosophy of the Talmud" by Rabbi Joseph Krauskopf, "Islam and the Koran" by Emil Nabokoff, "Philosophy and Religions of the Jains" by Vichand Raghavji Gandhi and others.<ref>{{cite news | title =The Monsalvat School | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =9 | date =3 Jul 1898 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528702/prospectus_outline_greenacre_program/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
[[File:Franklin Benjamin Sanborn photograph.jpg|thumb|left|210px|Franklin Sanborn in 1900]] A diary of [[Charles W. Chesnutt]] noted he was a replacement speaker for [[Walter Hines Page]] for a talk in 1899 on the condition of African-Americans in the South, and commented on witnessing a diversity of clothing representing cultures of the world.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Joseph McElrath Jr.|author2=Robert C. Leitz III|author3=Robert C. Leitz, III|title="To Be an Author": Letters of Charles W. Chesnutt, 1889–1905|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WlAABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA125|date=14 July 2014|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1-4008-6448-5|pages=125–126}}</ref> Farmer's farewell address for the 1899 season was printed in the [[Boston Evening Transcript]] and contained warm thoughts of the development of the work and its ongoing goals.<ref>{{cite news | title =Miss Farmer's partiing address at Greenacre | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =16 | date =Oct 18, 1899 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=18991018&id=tj9fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=d1QNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1443,5298301&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A beatific booklet ''Greenacre on the Piscataqua'' of some 22 pages with a section written in August 1899 and another in September 1900 was published.<ref name=Ingersoll/> Bahá'ís have identified a quote from the religion in the 1899 program and speculate Farmer had heard of the religion.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.27–9}}</small> However, in Farmer's life and the structure of Greenacre there was crisis.
