According to scholar Eric Leigh Schmidt Sanborn was working for a "creation of a new shrine" for transcendentalism akin to reforming the Concord school centered on Emerson and used his coverage work of Greenacre in newspaper stories to frame that development while at the same time Janes drifted explicitly from Farmer's approach by charging people for the classes and insisting on academic credentials and approaches to understand the diversity of religions.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.199–200}}</small> Janes' disconnect from Farmer had reached the point of shutting down the Monsalvat school.<ref>{{cite journal| last =Hollywood| first = Amy| title =Spiritual but Not Religious| journal =Harvard Divinity Bulletin| volume =38| issue =1–2| date =Winter–Spring 2010| url =http://bulletin.hds.harvard.edu/articles/winterspring2010/spiritual-not-religious| accessdate = July 28, 2015}}</ref> There were also tensions between Sanborn and Janes and among other groups.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Laurie F. Maffly-Kipp|author2=Leigh E. Schmidt|author3=Mark Valeri|title=Practicing Protestants: Histories of Christian Life in America, 1630–1965|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z-MxJ4iFqi8C&pg=PA218|date=14 July 2006|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-8361-3|page=218}}</ref> There had been speculation on Farmer being bought out,<ref>{{cite news | title =I hear that a New York syndicate ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =3 | date =23 Feb 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2286319/speculation_on_bahai_sarah_farmer_and/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> creditors were nervous,<ref>{{cite news | title =Was not at home | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =28 Sep 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366229/creditors_worried_about_greenacre_serve/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> and her business partners had thought to force Farmer to sell out.<ref name=Menon2/>
==Transformation==
===1900–1906===
====Farmer's encounter with the Bahá'í Faith==== While her partners were seeking to meet with her, Farmer was already aboard the [[SS Fürst Bismarck (1890)|SS ''Fürst Bismarck'']] out of New York as a guest of Maria P. Wilson<ref name=Rideout>{{cite web | last =Rideout | first = Anise | title =Early History of the Bahá'í Community in Boston, Massachusetts | publisher =bahai-library.com | date = 1940 | url =http://bahai-library.com/rideout_history_community_boston | accessdate =August 1, 2015 }} * For a picture see {{cite web | title =Sarah Jane Farmer and travel companions on the S.S. Furst Bismark, 1900 | website =Maine Historical Society | date =2000 | url =http://www.mainememory.net/artifact/16596 | accessdate = July 28, 2015}}</ref> trying to release herself of her worries in first week of January 1900.<ref name=Menon3>Menon says she was aboard on Jan 1: {{cite web | author=Jonathan Menon | title = Sarah J. Farmer: One of America's Great Religious Innovators | website =239days.com | date =August 23, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/23/sarah-j-farmer-american-religious-innovator/ | accessdate =July 28, 2015 }}; Rideout, just prior, says February 23, two newspaper clippings the ship left mid first week of January. *{{cite news | title =Mr. Stern will leave ... | newspaper = New-York Tribune | location =New York, New York | page =5 | date =2 Jan 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2917696/furst_bismark_headed_out_from_new_york/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Litchfield ... | newspaper =New-York Tribune | location =New York, New York | page =15 | date =7 Jan 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2917706/furst_bismarck_leaves_ny_see_sarah/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Wilson and Farmer ran into friends Josephine Locke and Elizabeth Knudson aboard ship - and eventually learned they were on the way to see [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] who was leader of a new religion and had in their possession an early prayer book.<ref name=Rideout/> Wilson was dubious but eventually the ladies changed their plans and went along. They waited in Egypt<ref>{{cite news | title = Theosophy in Italy | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =42 | date =22 Apr 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2918499/lillian_whiting_on_theosophy_in_italy/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> where there are pictures of her with [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]] and scenes there,<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.28,32}}</small> before leaving for Haifa March 23, 1900.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.29}}
A few years later her friend [[Mary Hanford Ford]] related some of what took place meeting `Abdu'l-Bahá as a second hand account. A few facts are detailed - Farmer had met `Abdu'l-Bahá and accepted the religion on one occasion, and on another wanted to ask him a series of questions in the context of a review of her whole life - but when she wrote it all down she left the notebook in the hurry of being called to come to him in the early morning. She reported he answered the questions spontaneously and in the right order starting in such a way that the translator was confused because no question had been asked. At the end of that interview she cried "... strange tears of ecstatic happiness, and went to her room to recover the composure which had been shaken by these surprising and illuminating events."<ref>{{cite book|author=Mary Hanford Finney Ford|title=The Oriental Rose: Or, The Teachings of Abdul Baha which Trace the Chart of "the Shining Pathway"|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b8EoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA176|year=1910|publisher=Broadway Publishing Company|pages=176–178}}</ref> This list of questions is referred to in another briefer recollection.<ref name=EsterDavvis>{{cite news | title =The Great Discovery |author= Esterh Davis | newspaper =Star of the West |volume =21 |number=11 | pages =330–334 | date =February 1931 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=21&page=330 | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Anise Rideout had a similar record of the incident.<ref name=Rideout/> Rideout reports that `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote an inscription in Farmer's Bible dated March 26. For Maria Wilson's part she also joined the religion and was the first Bahá'í to move to Boston.
After being in Haifa and Egypt the women also spent some time in [[Bahá'í Faith in France#Early days|Paris among a small group of Bahá'ís]] after the visit,<ref name=Rideout/><ref name="Remey1949">{{cite book|author=Charles Mason Remey|title=Reminiscences of the summer school Green-Acre, Eliot, Maine: of seasons there, of happenings there, and some of the people who went there and the things they did|url=http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/diglib/MSS/P-T/R/Remey/RGA.htm|orig-year=1949|year=1955|pages=7–8}}</ref> and Rome.<ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =29 Jun 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296803/sarah_farmer_on_return_trip_is_ill_in/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
====Back at Greenacre==== The Summer 1900 program went on without Farmer,<ref>* {{cite news | title =The Greenacre Inn at Eliot ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =18 Jun 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/658810/1900_june_18_greenacre_inn_managed_by/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Greenacre Inn | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =13 Jul 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2902662/greenacre_accommodations_and_program/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The Greenacre lectures | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =1 Aug 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2902684/greenacre_program_review/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =4 Aug 1900 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2902691/greenacre_happenings_with_farmer_away/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> though the Monsalvat school was suspended that year.<ref name=RichardsonOC/> Farmer returned to the United States in November,<ref name=Menon1/> injured on arrival according to one account.<ref name=EsterDavvis/> There were also reports that the translator at the meeting had come to the United States with Farmer on the return voyage.<ref name=EsterDavvis/> She was noted back in Eliot in May 1901.<ref>{{cite news | title =Miss Sarah J. Farmer returned ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =22 May 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2902745/bahai_sarah_farmer_returned_to_eliot/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> An organizational meeting came together May 22 and dedicated a site on nearby "Mount Monsalvat", as Farmer called it, to eventually host a school.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre Assembly | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =11 | date = May 25, 1901 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DZg-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=RVoMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6675%2C3543468 | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Kate C. Ives was among those present. That Spring of 1901 she also met with [[Phoebe Hearst]],<ref name="Remey1949"/> who herself had been to see `Abdu'l-Bahá a few years earlier and she too had adopted the religion.
Farmer was publicly linked with the religion in June 1901.<ref name=LillianGray>* {{cite news |author=Lillian Gray | title =Sarah Farmer and the Greenacre cult | newspaper =The Wilkes-Barre Record | location =Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania | page =12 | date =22 Jun 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2286337/bahai_sarah_farmer_and_greenacre_story/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }} * {{cite news |author=Lillian Gray | title =Sarah Farmer and the Green Acre Cult | newspaper =Evening Report | location =Lebanon, Pennsylvania | page =6 | date =22 Jun 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2286342/bahai_sarah_farmer_and_greenacre_story/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }} * {{cite news |author=Lillian Gray | title =Sarah Farmer and the Greenacre Cult | newspaper =The Fort Wayne Journal-Gazette | location =Fort Wayne, Indiana | page =11 | date =23 Jun 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2286351/bahai_sarah_farmer_and_greenacre_story/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }} * {{cite news |author=Lillian Gray | title =Sarah Farmer and the Greenacre cult | newspaper = San Antonio Express | location =San Antonio, Texas | page =14 | date =23 Jun 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366282/bahai_sarah_farmer_and_greenacre_story/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }} * {{cite news |author=Lillian Gray | title =Sarah Farmer and the Greenacre cult | newspaper = The Pittsburgh Press | location =Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | page =16 | date =Jun 23, 1901 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19010623&id=PhIbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i0gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3238,5066743&hl=en | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }}</ref> Of the Bahá'í Faith, it was explained, "... she has found the common faith in which all devout souls may unite and yet be free."<ref name=LillianGray/> At the time there were some 700 Bahá'ís in the United States.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.190}}
Amidst her conflict with Janes and new found attachment to the Bahá'í Faith she offered free classes in parallel, even conflicting on time, with Janes' Monsalvat school classes.<ref name=RichardsonOC/> In 1901 the charge for the entire season of classes with Janes' group was five dollars for the Monsalvat school<ref name=Walter>{{cite book|title=Transcendentalists in Transition: Popularization of Emerson, Thoreau, and the Concord School of Philosophy in the Greenacre Summer Conferences and the Monsalvat School (1894–1909) : the Roles of Charles Malloy and Franklin Benjamin Sanborn Before the Triumph of the Baha'i Movement in Eliot, Maine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zlR-AAAAMAAJ|year=1980|author=Kenneth Walter Cameron|publisher=Transcendental Books}}</ref>{{rp|p.126}} - in inflation terms that would be $140 in 2014.<ref name=inflation/>
Schmidt featured Farmer and Greenacre in a chapter "Freedom and Self-Surrender" of a book ''Restless Souls: The Making of American Spirituality'' published by the University of California Press in 2012:
<blockquote>The struggle at the heart of liberal spirituality ... was over the firmness and fragility of religious identity in the modern world. ... Was the point precisely the ''freedom'' of spiritual seeking? Or was the real point to find a well-marked path and to submit to the disciplines of a new religious authority in order to submerge the self in a larger relationship to God and community? ... Farmer's eventual acceptance of the Baha'i faith or "the Persian Revelation" ... discomfited her liberal, universalistic friends, many of whom preferred ongoing inquiry to actually finding one path to follow. For Farmer, the vision that she found in the Baha'i faith of a new age of religious unity, racial reconciliation, gender equality, and global peace was the fulfillment of Transcendentalism's reform impulses and progressivism's millennial dreams. To her skeptical associates, her turn to the Persian Revelation represented a betrayal of their deepest ideals as free-ranging seekers whose vision of a cosmopolitan piety dimmed at the prospect of one movement serving as a singular focus for the universal religion.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.184–6}}</small></blockquote>
Nevertheless, Farmer focused the efforts of the institution on Bahá'í themes. In her words in 1902:
<blockquote>My joy in the Persian Revelation is not that it reveals one of the streams flowing to the great Ocean of Life, Light and Love, but that it is a perfect mirror of that Ocean. What, in Green Acre, was a ''vision'' and a ''hope'' becomes, through it a ''blessed reality'' now. It has illuminated for me every other expression of Truth which I had hitherto known and place my feet on a Rock from which they cannot be moved. And it is the Manifestation of the Fatherhood - Behá'u'lláh (ed - as it was spelled in those days) - who had taught me to look away from even the Greatest and find within the One 'Powerful, Mighty, and Supreme' who is to be the Redeemer of my life. It is a Revelation of Unity such as I had never before found. By means of its Light, as shown the life of the Master Abbas Abdul Beha, I have entered into a joy greater than any I have hitherto known. Green Acre was established as a means to that end and in proportion as well lay aside all spirit of criticism of others and seek only to live the Unity we find, shall we be able to help others to the same divine realization.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.206}}</blockquote>
[[File:Abu'l-Fadl Gulpaygani-1.jpg|260px|thumb|<center>Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl-i-Gulpáygání</center>]] Farmer opened the 1901 session at Greenacre with an address "The Revelation of Bahá'u'lláh and its relation to the Monsalvat School" while others gave related talks - "The New Jerusalem, or the City We Want", "Lecture on the Persian Revelation", and "Utterances of Bahá'u'lláh."<ref name=centenary>{{cite book|title=The Bahá'i centenary, 1844–1944: a record of America's response to Bahá'o'lláh's call to the realization of the oneness of mankind, to commemorate the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of the Bahá'i faith|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s1fYAAAAMAAJ|year=1944|publisher=Bahá'í publishing committee|pages=212–214}}</ref> [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]], among the most scholarly trained Bahá'ís of the time, was there,<ref name=LillianGray/><ref name=Stockman>{{cite book|author=Robert H. Stockman|title=The Bahá'í Faith in America: Early expansion, 1900–1912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WMl-PgAACAAJ|year=1985|publisher=Bahá'í Pub. Trust|isbn=978-0-85398-388-0}}</ref>{{rp|p.80}}<ref name=Peculiar>* {{cite news | title =Peculiar faith of the Babist sect as revealed by a woman | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =48 | date =1 Dec 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24940/babibahai_history_reports_and/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Visit to the Babist Chief | newspaper =The Sun | location =New York, New York | page =6 | date =Nov 24, 1901 | url =http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201901%20Grayscale/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201901%20Jan-Dec%20Grayscale%20-%204309.pdf | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }}</ref> and his talk was "Lectures on the Revelations of the Báb and Bahá'u'lláh of Persia".<ref name=centenary/> Ali Kuli Khan, to serve as his translator, arrived in the United States in June.<ref>{{cite news | title =Came on the Minnehaha | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =24 | date =June 24, 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2155418/arrival_of_bahai_ali_kuli_khan/ | accessdate = April 25, 2015 }}</ref> Abu'l-Fadl had accompanied Anton Haddad, the first Bahá'í to live in the United States, on his return trip to America. They had been sent by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]].<ref name=Peculiar/> The later well known Bahá'í [[Agnes Baldwin Alexander]], later appointed to a high office of the religion, was also there.<ref>{{cite book| last = Alexander | first = Agnes Baldwin |editor=Barbara Sims | title = History of the Bahá'í Faith in Japan 1914–1938 | publisher = Japan Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year = 1977 | location = Osaka, Japan | page =21 | url =http://bahai-library.com/alexander_history_bahai_japan }}</ref> Esther Davis reports others were there that summer of 1901: she herself, Raffii, the translator at one of Farmer's meetings with `Abdu'l-Bahá, and "Mother Beecher" (Ellen Tuller Beecher.)<ref name=EsterDavvis/> [[Mary Hanford Ford]] was there giving one of her talks on literature,<ref name=centenary/> and it was at these classes with Abu'l-Fadl it is considered she joined the religion.<ref name=Stockman/><ref name=Whitehead>{{cite book | last =Whitehead | first =O. Z. | authorlink = O. Z. Whitehead | title =Some Baha'is to Remember | publisher =George Ronald | date =1983 | pages =145–152 | url =http://grbooks.com/george-ronald-publisher-books/heritage-books/some-bahais-to-remember-1317293329 | isbn =0-85398-148-5}}</ref> Out of this the community of [[Bahá'í Faith in Greater Boston|Bahá'ís began to form in Boston]]. Farmer and `Abdu'l-Bahá began an active exchange of letters some twenty-plus of his which were gathered and printed initially in 1909 and then the third edition in 1919.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.38}}<ref>{{cite book |author=`Abdu'l-Bahá | authorlink =`Abdu'l-Bahá | title =Tablets of Abdul-Baha Abbas | publisher = Bahá'í publishing society | volume =2 | edition =3rd | date =February 1919 |orig-year=1909 | location =Chicago, US | url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TAB/tab-288.html }}</ref>
Nevertheless, Farmer did not embark on a heavy handed approach to the presence of the religion and made various compromises to limit its mention and presence,<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.207}} and this fits the Bahá'í teaching about not [[Proselytism#Bahá'í Faith|proselytizing]].<ref name="hatcher">{{Cite book |last = Hatcher |first = W.S. |last2 = Martin |first2 = J.D. |year = 1998 |title = The Bahá'í Faith: The Emerging Global Religion |publisher = Harper & Row |location = New York, NY |isbn = 0-06-065441-4 | ref = harv |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IZmkG1ASirgC | page = 220}}</ref> Her problems did not go away though Janes suddenly died in the fall of 1901.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.196}} A memorial was held at Greenacre September 6.<ref name=West1902/> Fillmore Moore, the director of the Comparative Religion school after Janes, continued the criticism.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.210}} Others sided with Janes' views including Sanborn and investor [[Sara Chapman Bull]].<ref name=RichardsonOC/> Meanwhile, a number of eastern teachers presenting their own religions, beyond those of the Bahá'ís themselves, began to appear officially on the programs of Monsalvat School beyond those of academically interested non-believers - Muslim Shehadi Abd-Allah Shehadi in 1901,<ref>{{cite news | title =At Greenacre | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =25 Jul 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366242/shehabi_abdallah_talks_on_mohammed_and/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> (and later lived in Providence, RI and had a park named after him,)<ref>{{cite news | title =Camp Shehadi |author=George Zink | newspaper =Wonalancet Out Door club | location = | pages =4–6 | date =April 1996 | url =http://www.wodc.org/newsletter/1996-04.pdf | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Buddhist [[Sister Sanghamitta]] before she left for India as a new convert,<ref>{{cite news | title =The missionary in India |author=Ella Wheeler Wilcox | newspaper =Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =19 | date =24 Nov 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2369837/sister_sanghamitta_had_been_to_greenacre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> B. S. Kimura of Japan, in 1902, Dharmpala, M. Barukatulah, Baha Premanand in 1904, and C. Jinaradadaen in 1905.<ref name=TIN1907>{{cite news | title =Two schools side by side at Green Acre | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =23 | date =17 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343611/bahai_presence_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Fadl and Khan were profiled along with a review of the religion in 1903.<ref>{{cite news | title =Religious topica; A Babi at Green Acre (from the Sprinfield Republican) | newspaper =The American Cooperator | volume =2 | issue =14, | pages =18–20 | location = Lewiston, Maine | date =Sep 5, 1903 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=CzBFAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA11-PA119#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = August 7, 2015}}</ref>
[[Ralph Waldo Trine]] wrote a book while at Greenacre<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.153}} and published it in 1903.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ralph Waldo Trine|title=In Tune with the Infinite: Or Fullness of Peace, Power and Plenty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eWbonQEACAAJ|year=1903|publisher=Bell & Sons}}</ref> Additionally music concerts became more common - one of the first was directed by early Bahá'í Edward Kinney.<ref>{{cite news | title =At Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =13 Aug 1901 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366243/greenacre_events_bahai_edward_kinney/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Myron H. Phelps, as part of the transition of the Monsalvat School in his position as director in 1904 and 5<ref name=TIN1907/> gave a talk on the religion at the 1904 conference following his 1903 book, (though it was later judged to be full of inaccuracies by the Bahá'ís.)<ref>{{cite book |author1= Myron Henry Phelps |author2= Bahiyyih Khanum | title =Life and Teachings of Abbas Effendi | publisher = The Knickerbocker Press | date =1903 | location =New York, New York | url =http://bahai-library.com/khanum_phelps_abbas_effendi }}</ref><ref>* {{cite news | title = The Babs of Persia | newspaper =The New York Times | location =New York, New York | page =23 | date =15 Aug 1903 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/312483/myron_phelps_book_on_the_bahai_faith/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Message of a new religion | newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle | location =San Francisco, California | page =13 | date =3 Dec 1903 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/294013/san_francisco_chronicle/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Articles based on the work were printed in various journals, some noting Greenacre as well.<ref>Some of the parts are distributed at: * {{cite journal | author=Myron H. Phelps | title = The Master of Akka | journal =Theosophical Forum | volume =9 | issue =8 | pages =150–4 | date =December 1903 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=QkfSAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA150#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate =August 29, 2015 }} * part 4 - {{cite journal | author= Myron H Phelps | title =The One Religion | journal =Theosophical Quarterly | volume =3 | pages =224–33 | date =1905 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=AtCryGBfEQ8C&lpg=PA224&ots=Gk8uvc_jbW&pg=PA224#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = August 29, 2015}} * part 5 - {{cite journal | author= Myron H Phelps | title =The One Religion - Attainment of sanctification or Christhood | journal =Theosophical Quarterly | volume =3 | issue = | pages =302–210 | date =1905 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=AtCryGBfEQ8C&lpg=PA224&ots=Gk8uvc_jbW&pg=PA302#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate =August 29, 2015 }} * part 6 - {{cite journal | author= Myron H Phelps | title =The One Religion (part 6) | journal =Theosophical Quarterly | volume =3 | pages =391–397 | date =1905 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=AtCryGBfEQ8C&lpg=PA224&ots=Gk8uvc_jbW&pg=PA391#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate =August 29, 2015 }}</ref>
In the face of the changing realms of support [[Phoebe Hearst]] was particularly stabilizing for Farmer in 1902 followed by Helen E. Cole in 1906.<ref name=RichardsonOC/><ref name=BET1906>{{cite news | title =Green Acre for 1906 | newspaper = Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =34 | date =Jul 2, 1906 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=19060702&id=PI8-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=81kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3099,303322&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Another factor in the progress of Greenacre was that steamer boat service from Portsmouth ran regularly in 1895,<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.16}} and the arrival of electric train service in Eliot near the hotel in 1902.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Will open up a delightful locality to the public | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =19 Apr 1902 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/346843/1902_april_19_terminus_of_the_train/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Heavy travel to Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =28 Jul 1902 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/346868/1902_july_28_heavy_train_service_to/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =That many people ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =4 Aug 1902 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/346881/1902_aug_04_many_residents_never_saw/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Finally in 1902 Farmer initiated a voluntary board - a "Fellowship" - "a sustaining body to help carry forward the Green Acre Conferences of which Sarah J. Farmer is the director."<ref name=DET1913>{{cite news | title =The Green Acre Conference | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =8 | date =Jul 25, 1913 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=19130725&id=9YonAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lwQGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2738,3634857&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Amidst this Farmer's personal home burned to the ground in 1904,<ref name=Atkinson1990/> and Randolph Bolles, whose sister and niece were well known Bahá'ís, took up residence living there until he died in 1939.<ref>{{cite news | title =Randolph Bolles | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =12 | date =21 Jul 1939 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296456/relative_of_maxwell_bahais_randolph/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> {{Location map many | USA Massachusetts | width = 250 | caption = Green Acre and Boston | lat2 = 42.38006 | long2 = -71.11298 |position2=right| label2 = Boston | lat3 = 43.111 | long3 = -70.794 |position3=bottom | outside = 1 | label3 = Green Acre | outside3 = 1 <!-- Turn off error category due to location outside map--> | lat4 = 42.38006 | long4 = -71.11298 |position4=left | label4 = Cambridge }}
====Year of Peace==== In 1904 and 1905 Japanese diplomats visited Greenacre - [[Yokoyama Taikan]], [[Okakura Kakuzō]] and Kentok Hori, signing Farmer's autograph book with quotations and drawings for a special tea service and presentations.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.44–6}}</small> As an institution Greenacre developed a brief set of "branch" associations including one in Washington D.C. in 1905<ref>{{cite news| title =Local Branch Formed; Green-Acre Fellowship Association Organized here| newspaper =Evening star| location =Washington, D.C.| page =14 | date =April 27, 1905| url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1905-04-27/ed-1/seq-14/| accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref> that began to host peace conferences.<ref>{{cite news | title =Address by founder of Green-Acre | newspaper =The Washington Post | location =Washington, District of Columbia | page =6 | date =15 Apr 1905 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/657528/1905_april_15_address_by_found_of/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Peace conference at All Souls' | newspaper =The Washington Post | location =Washington, District of Columbia | page =34 | date =16 Apr 1905 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/657509/1905_april_16_peace_conference_arranged/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Candler talks of Peace | newspaper =The San Francisco Call | location =San Francisco, California | page =2 | date =17 Apr 1905 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/354094/1905_april_17_senator_chandler_talks_of/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
Farmer's connections and determination for peace was such that she was present at the signing of the [[Treaty of Portsmouth|Portsmouth Peace Treaty]] and indeed was the only woman on the naval base.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.50–51}}</small><ref>{{cite web | title =New Hampshire Humanities Council, Chautauqua 2005; "America Reinvents Itself 1905" | publisher =Japan-America Society of New Hampshire | date =2005 | url =http://www.portsmouthpeacetreaty.com/Chautauqua.cfm | accessdate =August 28, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =Green Acre Baha'i School Presents Portsmouth Peace Treaty Events August 21 - September 5, 2005 | publisher =Japan-America Society of New Hampshire | date =2005 | url =http://www.portsmouthpeacetreaty.com/greenacre081505.cfm | accessdate =August 28, 2015 }}</ref> The event was remembered in more recent times.<ref>{{cite journal | title =Community Briefs; The Peace Treaty in Portsmouth | journal =The York Independent | volume =12 | issue =14 | page =6 | location =York, Maine | date =July 20, 2010 | url =http://www.yorkindependent.net/TYI_0716.pdf | accessdate = July 28, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Ambassador talks peace at Green Acre | newspaper =Baha'i World News Service | publisher =Baha'i International Community | date =13 September 2005 | url =http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/2005/050913.html | accessdate = July 28, 2015}}</ref> Diplomats from the treaty meeting attended functions at Greenacre.<ref name=Robinson2013/> Some 300 attended, including a few reporters from Japan, though President Roosevelt and the Russian delegation did not.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.47–9}}</small> There were several talks presented on peace including by Minister Takahira and Ali Kuli Khan, who, in a letter to his wife, called it the most important day in the history of Green Acre to that point.
At the same time a few became interested in the Bahá'í Faith at Green Acre - Harlan Ober and Alfred E. Lunt were Bostonians who joined the religion in the summer of 1905 at Greenacre<ref name=Stockman/><small>{{rp|pp.218–9}}</small> with Ober learning of the religion first through [[Lua Getsinger]]<ref name=JourneyWedding>{{cite web | title =The Wedding of Grace & Harlan Ober | website =thejourneywest.org | date =July 17, 2012 | url =http://www.thejourneywest.org/2012/07/17/the-wedding-of-grace-harlan-ober/ | accessdate = June 16, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150616162820/http://www.thejourneywest.org/2012/07/17/the-wedding-of-grace-harlan-ober/ | archivedate = June 16, 2015}}</ref> and Alice Buckton,<ref name=RandallObit>{{cite news | title =William H. Randall, 1863–1929 |author=Ruth Wales Randall | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=20 |number=1 | pages =22–24 | date =April 1929 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=20&page=22 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> and then Lunt learned of the religion from Ober.<ref name=MothersStories>{{cite web | author=Muriel Ives Barrow Newhall | title =Mother's stories and Stories of Abdu'l-Baha as told by Mother | website =Bahai-Library.com | date = 1998 |origyear=1970 | url =http://bahai-library.com/ives/stories/MSTORIES.PDF | accessdate = June 1, 2015}}</ref> [[File:Harlan Ober in 1907.jpg|left|thumb|Harlan Ober in 1907]][[File:Alfred E. Lunt(1910).jpg|thumb|left|Alfred E. Lunt (1910)]]Ober had been in shipping interests.<ref name=RandallObit/> Ober and Lunt were leaders in Republican party politics on college campuses,<ref>{{cite news | title =Forming College Clubs | newspaper = The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =2 | date =22 Sep 1908 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/382084/1908_sept_22_harlan_ober_and_alfred/ | accessdate = 26 Feb 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Mounts to Marshall spellbinders | newspaper =The Inter Ocean | location =Chicago, Illinois | page =3 | date =27 Aug 1904 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2567509/later_bahai_alfred_e_lunt_of_harvard/ | accessdate = 7 Jun 2015}}</ref> in the era of the [[Fourth Party System]] also known as the [[Progressive Era]]. About 1905 a formal board to supervise Greenacre called the "Green Acre Fellowship" superseded the earlier voluntary one and was arranged with five trustees - Francis Keefe, Aldred E. Lunt, Horatio Dresser, Maria Wilson, and Fillmore Moore, (two were Bahá'í, three not.)<ref name=PH1913>{{cite news | title =No hint of controversy | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =30 Jun 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296263/continued_issues_at_green_acre_with/ | accessdate = January 21, 2014}}</ref>
In the summer of 1906 [[Stanwood Cobb]] learned of the religion from a series of articles in the ''Boston Transcript'' and went to Green Acre to learn more.<ref name=Schmidt/><ref>{{cite book | author=Stanwood Cobb | authorlink =Stanwood Cobb | title =In His Presence:Visits to 'Abdu'l-Bahá | chapter =Memories of `Abdu'l-Bahá 1908: 1910: 1912: 1913 | chapterurl =http://bahai-library.com/wilhelm_cobb_his_presence&chapter=2 | publisher = Kalimat Press | date =1989 | pages =25–29 | url =http://bahai-library.com/wilhelm_cobb_his_presence | isbn =0-933770-71-5 }}</ref><small>{{rp|pp.216,224}}</small> He conversed with Sarah Farmer.<ref name="rest">{{cite book|author=Leigh Eric Schmidt|title=Restless Souls: The Making of American Spirituality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wbk80IOIgzEC&pg=PA218|date=6 August 2012|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-95411-3|page=218}}</ref> [[Thornton Chase]], the "first occidental Bahá'í" was also there giving a series of talks.<ref>{{cite web | author=Robert Stockman | title =Robert Stockman's Notes in the National Bahá'í Archives | website =h-net.org | date =1986 | url =http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/notes/vol2/chs.1906.html | accessdate = June 28, 2015}}</ref> It was on that occasion that Cobb joined the religion.<ref name="world">{{cite book | title =The Bahá'í World |author=Ruth L. Dunbar |chapter=In Memoriam: Stanwood Cobb, 1881–1982 | publisher =Bahá'í World Centre | volume =18 | date = 1986 | pages =814–816 | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/800-825.html | isbn = }}</ref> Others were also there giving talks,<ref>* {{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =27 Jun 1906 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528740/monsalvat_comparative_religion_school/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre (continued) | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =27 Jun 1906 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528742/monsalvat_comparative_religion_school/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015}}</ref> as well as a meeting of civil war veterans.<ref>* {{cite news | title = At Green Acre | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =30 Jul 1906 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366262/war_veterans_meet_at_green_acrei/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre (continued) | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =30 Jul 1906 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2366268/veterans_meet_at_green_acre_ii/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> [[Ponnambalam Ramanathan]]'s talk that year was featured in the [[Boston Evening Transcript]].<ref>{{cite news | title =The Unity of faith | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =11 | date =Jul 31, 1905 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=19050731&id=YrM0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=-eAIAAAAIBAJ&pg=6695,4019642&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
Others also came to Greenacre. In 1906 among others noted, then [[United States Assistant Secretary of State#Third Assistant Secretary of State|Third assistant Secretary of State]] [[Huntington Wilson]], then retired General [[O. O. Howard]], and Ex-Governor [[John Green Brady]] of Alaska all gave talks or hosted meetings.<ref name=BET1906/> [[Marsden Hartley]] took a job as a handyman there and through his association he secured his first exhibition,<ref>{{cite web| last =Peltakian| first = Danielle| title =Marsden Hartley; American Expressionist| publisher =sullivangoss.com| year =2011| url =http://www.sullivangoss.com/marsden_Hartley/ | accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref> and was friends with Ober and Lunt.<ref>{{cite book|author=Townsend Ludington|title=Marsden Hartley: The Biography of an American Artist|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X_QoI5GGGCsC&pg=PA52|year=1992|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0-8014-8580-0|pages=51–52}}</ref>
===1907–1912=== In 1907 it was still possible to review things at Greenacre without mentioning Bahá'ís.<ref>{{cite book|title=Looking into Walt Whitman: American Art, 1850Ð1920|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wUsQxS6_fm4C&pg=PA150|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=0-271-04780-1|page=150}}</ref> [[May Wright Sewall]] spoke in 1907 at Green Acre.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Rachel J. Lapp|author2=Anita K. Stalter|title=More Than Petticoats: Remarkable Indiana Women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=73CbA7VWs4YC&pg=PA34|date=1 November 2006|publisher=Globe Pequot Press|isbn=978-0-7627-3806-9|page=34}}</ref> Newspaper coverage began to cover the division and resolution at Greenacre<ref name=TIN1907/> and Farmer managed to keep the reputation of Greenacre high through 1907.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.210}} Coverage of events occurred in Indianapolis.<ref>* {{cite news | title = Green Acre and its high aims | newspaper = The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =12 | date =27 Jul 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/656489/1907_july_27_sarah_farmer_energetic/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Serene study of many religions | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =13 | date =3 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343586/profile_of_green_acre_studies_with/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Serene study of many religions (continued) | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =14 | date =3 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343583/profile_of_green_acre_studies_with/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title = A teacher at Green Acre | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =23 | date =17 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/343613/mirza_abdul_fazl_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =New religion does not combat old | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =13 | date =31 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/328329/green_acre_talk_echoed_in_indianap1_1/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =New religion does not combat old (continued) | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =15 | date =31 Aug 1907 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/328344/green_acre_talk_echoed_in_indianapt_2/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
Bahá'ís sometimes objected that contradictory ideas were presented together while others sometimes objected there was too much Bahá'í coverage.<ref name=Stockman/><small>{{rp|pp.217–8}}</small> `Abdu'l-Bahá's advise to Farmer was to be more direct about the religion and less supportive of "mouldered, two thousand years old superstitions".<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.208–9,313}}</small> However, in 1907 other events took hold when, at the age of 60, Farmer fell off a train car in Boston, was injured and never fully recovered.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.190,210–1}}</small> She checked herself into [[McLean Hospital]] possibly with a severe injury to her back, when it was a [[sanitorium]].<ref name=Robinson2013/>
The 1908 season went on though with perhaps a reduced schedule.<ref>{{cite news | title = Two days at Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =22 Aug 1908 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528747/monsalvat_comparative_religion_school/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Fillmore Moore pressed her to surrender the right of trustee appointing and issued a pained statement in 1909.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.53}} Writer Diane Iverson feels Farmer progressed in her hospitalization over a broken heart from the contention over Greenacre.<ref name=Robinson2013/> Her care transferred to a [[private duty nurse]] in Portsmouth and from there, when she "became 'too much to handle'", into the care of early psychologist Dr. Edward Cowles.<ref name=Robinson2013/>
Farmer's last public appearance at Green Acre was in 1909.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.210}} The season was successful with singer Mary Lucas<ref>{{cite news | title =Events of Eliot | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =14 Jul 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703466/bahai_mary_lucas_soprano_giving/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> (who had joined the religion in 1905,)<ref name=MaryLucas>{{cite web |author=Mary L. Lucas | title =A brief account of my visit to Acca | website =Bahai-library.com | date =1905 | url =http://bahai-library.com/pdf/l/lucas_my_visit_acca.pdf | accessdate =August 28, 2015 }}</ref> and many others.<ref>* {{cite news | title = This morning at Green Acre ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =19 Jul 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703570/speakers_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The rain caused Thursday's ... | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =6 Aug 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2654648/mrs_charles_johnston_gives_talk_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title = The Sunday services at Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =23 Aug 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2928114/green_acre_session_inc_bahai_mirza/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Eliot, Me. Aug. 25 ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =25 Aug 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/299260/concert_and_talks_and_bahai_mirza/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Friday's program at Green Acre ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =26 Aug 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296951/bahai_mirza_sinore_raffie_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =A good audience assembled at Green Acre ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =31 Aug 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703591/speakersperformances_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Events of Eliot | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =1 Sep 1909 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2567581/green_acre_events/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> That year the Green Acre Fellowship board voted to rebuild Farmer's residence on the site of her father's home at a cost of $5000.<ref name=DET1913/>
Farmer changed her will to bequeath Greenacre to the Bahá'ís in the event of her death via an agent of Phoebe Hearst.<ref name=Atkinson1990/><ref>{{cite news | title =Hooe will is filed | newspaper =The Washington Herald | location =Washington, District of Columbia | page =12 | date =13 Jan 1911 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/656469/1911_jan_13_green_acre_was_to_go_to/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Her family involuntarily committed her to a mental institution<ref name=MothersStories/><ref>* {{cite news | title =Depositions are being taken | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =25 Jul 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/655942/1914_july_24_relatives_of_sarah_farmer/ | accessdate = July 8, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Feb24 - Judge Hoyt ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =31 Dec 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/656452/1914_dec_31_judge_hoyt_declared_sarah/ | accessdate =July 8, 2015}}</ref> in July 1910,<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.190,210–1}}</small> At the same time the by-laws of the institution allowed Farmer to appoint 3 of its 5 trustees, fill vacancies, and remove any of the trustees.<ref name=DET1913/> All this was just before the centenary of the town of Eliot itself was celebrated including at Greenacre.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Aaron Burr Cole|author2=John Lemuel Murray Willis|title=History of the centennial of the incorporation of the town of Eliot, Maine, August 7th-13, 1910|url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008650846|year=1912|publisher=Augustine Caldwell}}</ref> Meanwhile, early Canadian Bahá'ís, the Magees, began to be regular summer visitors.<ref name=Hoonaard>{{cite book|author=Will C. Van den Hoonaard|title=The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of Canada, 1898–1948|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=znXIbkNA1nQC&pg=PA23|accessdate=20 September 2013|year=1996|publisher=Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press|isbn=978-0-88920-272-6|pages=22–23, 86}}</ref> Among the several presenters and singers were a few Bahá'ís,<ref>* {{cite news | title =At Green Acre this morning ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =19 Jul 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703554/bahai_mary_lucas_recital_for_sarah/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The song recital at Green Acre ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =21 Jul 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703601/green_acre_recital_for_sarah_farmer/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre on Wednesday ... | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =2 Aug 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/424569/1910_aug_02_remey_spoke_on_the_bahai/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre on Wednesday ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =30 Aug 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2654963/bahai_elizabeth_t_stansell_others/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre on Wednesday ... (continued) | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =30 Aug 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2654968/bahai_elizabeth_t_stansell_others/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> as well as [[W. E. B. Du Bois]] and [[Swami Paramananda]]. <ref>{{cite news | title =At Green Acre on Sunday ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =6 Aug 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2528754/green_acre_talks_dubois_dawn_camp/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Ali Kuli Khan was appointed Iranian Charge D'Affaires in Washington D. C. in 1910.<ref>{{cite news | title =Persia's new envoy | newspaper =The New York Times | location =New York, New York | page =4 | date =2 Sep 1910 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/667614/bahai_mirza_kuli_khan_presents/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }}</ref>
A review of the history of Greenacre was published in 1911 in the local paper though there was more description of the alienness of Vivekananda in racist terms.<ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre's own story | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =6 Jun 1911 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2928341/story_of_greenacre_founding_mrs_ole/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> The season had many speakers.<ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre conferences in full swing | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =18 Jul 1911 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/357280/1911_july_18_bahai_revelation_spoken_of/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
====`Abdu'l-Bahá in the area====
{{main|`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West}} [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, embarked on travels to the West following release from imprisonment.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Bahais and Abbas Effendi | newspaper =(from the Boston Herald) The Charlotte Observer | location =Charlotte, North Carolina | page =3 | date =21 Feb 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2655300/profile_anticipating_abdulbaha_to/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Bahais and Abbas Effendi (from the Boston Herald)(continued) | newspaper =The Charlotte Observer | location =Charlotte, North Carolina | page =3 | date =21 Feb 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2655309/profile_anticipating_abdulbaha_to/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}}</ref> While the regular season at Greenacre ran in July,<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre conferences | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =6 Jul 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703558/bahai_mary_lucas_on_singing_program_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> he was there from 16 to 23 August.<ref name=Parsons>{{cite book| last = Parsons| first = Agnes| editor-last = Hollinger| editor-first = Richard| title = `Abdu'l-Bahá in America; Agnes Parsons' Diary| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=C2r6CO1qqL4C&pg=PA3| year = 1996| publisher = Kalimat Press| location = US| isbn = 978-0-933770-91-1 }}</ref><ref name="Mahmud">{{cite book| last = Zarqānī| first = Maḥmūd.| title = Mahmúd's Diary Chronicling `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey to America| url = http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131228031741/http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary| archivedate = 28 December 2013| origyear = 1913| year = 1998| publisher = George Ronald| location = Oxford, UK| isbn = 978-0-85398-418-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Abdul Baha at Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =14 Aug 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296247/abdulbaha_at_green_acre_portsmouth/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá referred to renaming it "Green Acre" vs "Greenacre" in relation to the Bahá'í presence where the founder of the religion is buried - referring to [[Acre, Israel#Ottoman era|Acre, Syria]].<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.207}} Though Farmer herself referred to "Green Acre" since 1902<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.206}} and publicly in 1903<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.195}} and the formation documents of the Fellowship also used "Green Acre"<ref name=DET1913/> - nevertheless Schmidt notes the change in use as a dividing line among the groups involved.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.185}} Another name sometimes used is "Green-acre-on-the-Piscataqua" dating from 1897<ref>{{cite journal | title =American Institute of Electrical Engineers | journal =American Electrician | volume =9 | issue =4 | page =130 | date =April 1897 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=Z9RLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA130#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = August 11, 2015}}</ref> and in modern times.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> Greenacre itself as a name for the site seems to predate the building of the hotel.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.10–11}}</small>
Some five<ref name=Ward239Days>{{cite book| last = Dr. Ward| first = Allan L.| title = 239 Days; `Abdu'-Bahá's Journey in America| year = 1979| publisher = US Bahá'í Publishing Trust| isbn = 978-0-87743-129-9 }}</ref>{{rp|p.125}} or eight hundred people were there to hear `Abdu'l-Bahá's first talk.<ref name=1stday>{{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = The Methods for Investigating Truth | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 17, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/17/the-methods-of-investigating-reality/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }}</ref> The talk was about ways of knowing the truth - he disavowed individual approaches like pure reason, simple authority, individual inspiration, etc., but affirmed:
<blockquote>[A] statement presented to the mind accompanied by proofs which the senses can perceive to be correct, which the faculty of reason can accept, which is in accord with traditional authority and sanctioned by the promptings of the heart, can be adjudged and relied upon as perfectly correct, for it has been proved and tested by all the standards of judgment and found to be complete.<ref name=1stday/></blockquote>
Some repudiated their former beliefs in the sanctity in pure inspiration.<ref name=Ward239Days/>{{rp|p.125}}
`Abdu'l-Bahá then visited Farmer at her home.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|60}}
That evening `Abdu'l-Bahá addressed the audience at the Eirenion and he wrote a prayer for Farmer.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.60–1}}</small> He was in the program speaking August 16, 17, 18, and 19 with Herbert Peckham speaking at most of the remaining schedule of the week. Several of `Abdu'l-Bahá's talks were gathered and published in ''The Promulgation of Universal Peace'' pages 253-275.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.63}} He also visited the homes of other Bahá'ís - Mason Remey, Carrie and Edward Kinney. At other talks members of the audience wept during his prayers or fainted. He spoke to a girls club camp group by the river on August 19.<ref name=Ward239Days/>{{rp|p.127}} In a letter he declared Farmer was not insane but experiencing "religious exultation" and not suffering from [[female hysteria]] as these things were viewed in the day.<ref name=Robinson2013/> He met with individuals on other days at Green Acre or the home of Kate Ives, the first woman member of the religion,<ref>{{cite book|author=Will C. van den Hoonaard|title=The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of Canada, 1898-1948|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=znXIbkNA1nQC&pg=PA17|date=16 December 1996|publisher=Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press|isbn=978-0-88920-272-6|page=17}}</ref> offering advice and a listening ear to each.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.75}}
Fred Mortensen arrived August 20.<ref name=Ward239Days/>{{rp|p.126}}<ref>{{cite web | author= Robert Sockett | author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = Fred Mortensen Rides the Rails | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 20, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/20/fred-mortensen-rides-the-rails/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last =Penoyer | first = Justin | title =Mortensen, Fred | publisher =Bahai-library.com | year = 2007 | url =http://bahai-library.com/penoyer_fred_mortensen | accessdate = August 1, 2015}}</ref> Mortensen had been a criminal that fled arrest - his lawyer was Bahá'í Albert Hall of Minnesota from whom he learned of the religion. Riding from Minneapolis to Cleveland he then went on to Green Acre - all by way of [[Freighthopping]]. Being introduced in a crowd he was embarrassed at his dirty appearance and then was told to sit down amid the company of people in fine dress and wait but soon `Abdu'l-Bahá returned and began to speak closely with Mortensen His inquiry revealed how Mortensen had traveled. {{multiple image <!-- Essential parameters --> | align = right | direction = horizontal | footer = Panorama of those at feast of `Abdu'l-Bahá at Green Acre;<br>`Abdu'l-Bahá is seated in the right most picture on the far left. | image1 = Left-most part of panorama of participants of `Abdu'l-Bahá's feast at Green Acre.jpg | width1 = 200 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Part of panorama during `Abdu'l-Bahá's visit.jpg | width2 = 180 | alt2 = | image3 = Abdul Baha in Green Acre.jpg | width3 = 200 | alt3 = }}
Mortensen had arrived on a day `Abdu'l-Baha had arranged as a feast<ref name=Ward239Days/>{{rp|p.129}} which was held on "Mount Monsalvat" and a large panomramic picture taken.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.76–7}}</small> Mortensen is seated farthest on the left. Farmer was also reportedly there led by the hand by `Abdu'l-Bahá across the hill for a few minutes and had a long conversation then publicly pointed out the area would be host to the second Bahá'í Temple for America as well as a university and then praised Farmer openly.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.78–9}}</small>
There followed a few more talks and farewell visits on topics like elimination of prejudice. He was said to characterize the work as "like that of the exhausted iron worker's apprentice whose master said to him 'Die, but pump.'<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.81}}
`Abdu'l-Bahá again visited Farmer and they went on a car tour including a stop to view the shipyard where the treaty had been signed.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.72}} On the return trip she was not allowed to step off the car when it stopped at Green Acre.<ref name=Menon1/>
On the last day at Green Acre he met with individuals and then left stopping at Farmer's hospitalization again this time by carriage - she wept at his feet on that occasion.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.211–5}}</small><ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.81}}
==Bahá'í management==
===1913–1916=== With news that Farmer was visible, if only briefly, her health was celebrated, but the "more urgent" appeal by some was to warn people that Green Acre was "threatened with dire calamity" in June 1913.<ref>* {{cite news | title =The Green Acre controversy nearing end | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =21 Jun 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296250/bahai_faith_at_green_acre_controversy/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title = The Green Acre controversy nearing end (continued) | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =21 Jun 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296255/bahai_faith_at_green_acre_controversy/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Rallying to save Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =26 Jun 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/358571/1913_june_26_rallying_to_save_greenacre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A meeting in June seemed to present a calm front, and noted Farmer had previously appointed a guardian while she was indisposed,<ref name=PH1913/> but the controversy continued in July.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Denounce attempt to steal Greenacre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =26 Jul 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2767995/taking_sides_on_future_of_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> What had happened was that the terms of the trust Green Acre had specified authority resting on Farmer as long as she could direct the program.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> However, in 1913 she could not and a re-arrangement was undertaken by the board allowing a trustee to run the conference and maintain the program - a step feared by the Sanborn and Fillmore affiliated groups.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> Sanborn published arguments over rights of access.<ref name=DET1913/> Public rallies were echoed in print in ''Open Court'' and newspapers especially opposing a sense of the religious self-surrender and the foreignness of the Bahá'í Faith.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.221–3}}</small> Nevertheless, the board was expanded to nine members and William Randall, shipping businessman<ref>{{cite book|author=Margaret A. Elliott|title=Eliot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E1R61y7NyYIC&lpg=PA98&ots=bwVAWpByN8&pg=PA98|year=2005|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-3771-9|page=98}}</ref> and Bahá'í since before 1912,<ref>{{cite web | author=Caitlin Shayda Jones| author2=Jonathan Menon | editor1=Jonathan Menon |editor2=Shahin Sobhani | title = William Henry Randall and a Glass of Grape Juice | publisher =239 Days in America; a social media documentary | date =August 29, 2012 | url =http://239days.com/2012/08/29/william-harry-randall-and-a-glass-of-grape-juice/ | accessdate = June 20, 2015 }}</ref> was appointed a trustee,<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.83}} and only one was not a Bahá'í.<ref name=Schmidt/>{{rp|p.211}} Scary headlines in various places continued near and far.<ref>* {{cite news | title =A big row over "Pagan Temple" | newspaper = The Evening Kansan-Republican | location =Newton, Kansas | page =2 | date =11 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2059820/green_acre_election_split_over_bahais/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Row over "Pagan Temple" | newspaper =Arkansas City Daily Traveler | location =Arkansas City, Kansas | page =4 | date =12 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1327582/arkansas_city_daily_traveler/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Lively war over "Pagan Temple" | newspaper = The Allentown Democrat | location =Allentown, Pennsylvania | page =3 | date =12 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/667526/unbalanced_coverage_of_election_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title = Plan for a new colony | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =13 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/402439/1913_august_13_anti_bahist_favor_estab/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Ex-Gov. Waller in losing faction | newspaper = The Day | location =New London, Connecticut | page =4 | date =Aug 14, 1913 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19130814&id=aUkiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rnQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6839,4524756&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Persian diplomat here rouses Bahaists' ire | newspaper =The Washington Herald | location =Washington, District of Columbia | page =3 | date =15 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2059864/further_on_split_at_green_acre_over/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A program was carried on regardless.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.83}} Kate Ives, the first Bahá'í of Boston, wrote a letter to the editor inviting Portsmouth residents to a talk on the religion.<ref>{{cite news | title =At Grange hall | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =16 Aug 1913 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/296267/bahai_meeting_about_green_acre_talk/ | accessdate = June 21, 2015}}</ref> Debates began about who was Farmer's guardian started in January 1914 with news there was another guardian of her affairs.<ref>{{cite news | title =Petitions for new guardian | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =6 Jan 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/655948/1914_jan_06_sarah_farmer_asks_sanford/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> But Farmer then had been declared sane in February,<ref>{{cite news | title =Feb24 - Judge Hoyt ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =31 Dec 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/656452/1914_dec_31_judge_hoyt_declared_sarah/ | accessdate =July 8, 2015}}</ref> though the matter was raised again in March when Farmer's family sought to have her guardian appointed by them.<ref>{{cite news | title = State gleanings | newspaper = The Lewiston Daily Sun | location = Lewiston, Maine | page =9 | date =Mar 17, 1914 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1928&dat=19140317&id=pbUgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fWkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4786,4425700&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Amidst partisan charges in the newspaper the doctor agreed Farmer was sane and competent to run her own affairs in June.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bahaists in control of Greenacre colony | newspaper = The Sun | location =New York, New York | page =6 | date =29 Jun 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2059887/split_moving_over_bahais_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
Meanwhile, in May 1914 Alfred E. Lunt was elect to the national leadership of the religion<ref>{{cite news | title =Sixth annual convention of Bahai Temple Unity, Chicago, April 25–28, 1914 |author=Alfred E. Lunt | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=5, | number=4 | pages =51–53 | date =May 17, 1914 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=51 | accessdate =June 19, 2015 }}</ref> along with William Randall.<ref>{{cite news | title =Afternoon Session |author=Alfred E. Lunt | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=5 |number=10 | page =150 | date =September 8, 1914 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=150 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 }}</ref>
The controversy at Green Acre grew more tense. In July Farmer's mental condition was challenged with complaints and support statements all brought into court again as well as the rightful jurisdiction of two guardians of Farmer raised to superior courts.<ref>{{cite news | title =Depositions are being taken | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =25 Jul 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/655942/1914_july_24_relatives_of_sarah_farmer/ | accessdate = July 8, 2015}}</ref>
The July 1914 program at Green Acre went on - it included a talk by later Bahá'í Howard Colby Ives which was printed in the newspaper,<ref>{{cite news | title =Green acre conference | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =10 Jul 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1806552/talk_by_later_bahai_howard_colby_ives/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> as well as Alice Breed, Alfred E. Lunt, and others,<ref>{{cite news | title = Miss Farmer remembered | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =23 Jul 1914 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/358503/1914_july_23_miss_farmer_remembered/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> while others gave protesting talks from the street.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.209–10}}</small> The Fellowship board of Green Acre had argued over money ultimately in court which was settled, but the propriety of the expanded elected board was affirmed and required by-law amendments to be not just by the trustees but by the whole group of investors.<ref>{{cite news | title =Must restore Greenacre money | newspaper =Boston Evening Transcript | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =9 | date =Aug 10, 1914 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=19140810&id=jFEnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2AMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1294,1495896&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
Early Canadian Bahá'í Hariet Magee died at Green Acre in January 1915.<ref name=Hoonaard/> Early in 1915 Randall oversaw the electrification of the Inn and driveway.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.165}} Following the Bahá'í participation at the [[Panama–Pacific International Exposition]] in spring 1915,<ref>{{cite news | title =Beha followers to attend conference (continued) | newspaper =The Oregon Daily Journal | location =Portland, Oregon | page =10 | date =15 Apr 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1279331/portland_bahais_to_attend_san/ | accessdate = 11 Nov 2014}}</ref> Lunt again served on the national board of Bahá'ís in the United States;<ref name=300Baha/> this time as president,<ref>{{cite news | title =Foreword | newspaper =Star of the West | volume=6 | number=17 | pages =131–132 | date =Jan 19, 1916 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=06&page=131 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 }}</ref> with Ober as secretary.<ref>{{cite news | title =The first session of the Convention and the third session of the Congress |author=Louis Gregory | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=7 |number= 7 | pages =53–54 | date =July 13, 1916 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=53 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> Bahá'ís then began to buy several neighboring properties to Green Acre.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.86}} Still Farmer was not released from hospitalization despite several rounds of judging her sane and fit to mind her own affairs and she had been treated with drugs and [[electroshock therapy]].<ref name=Robinson2013/> Now Bahá'ís began to plan for Farmer's release - primarily William Randall, [[Urbain Ledoux]], and Montford Mills<ref name=Schmidt/><ref name=RichardsonOC/><ref name=MothersStories/><small>{{rp|pp.211–2}}</small><ref name=Lead>{{cite book|author1=Daniel Leab|title=Encyclopedia of American Recessions and Depressions [2 volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qI6dAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA454|date=15 January 2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-946-2|pages=454–457 | contribution =Ledoux, Urbain (1874–1941) | contribution-url =https://books.google.com/books?id=qI6dAwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA457&ots=ODAXEGcdjM&pg=PA454#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> - and tried various approaches. Ultimately they gathered a chief of police and a judge to accompany a court order with some intercepting the doctor physically and others carried Farmer to a waiting car to effect her freedom.<ref name=Lead/><ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre head taken with force | newspaper = Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =1 | date =Aug 4, 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1338073/bahai_urbain_ledoux_and_rescue_of/ | accessdate = Nov 28, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Miss Sarah Farmer secures release from Sanitorium | newspaper =The Lewiston Daily Sun | location = Lewiston, Maine | page =38 | date =Jul 27, 1916 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1928&dat=19160727&id=x7IgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TGkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4447,1831446&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A cousin of Farmer, Helen Green, also
