| title =Green Acre happenings | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =14 Aug 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1253693/greenacre_meeting_includes_some_bahais/ | accessdate = 5 Nov 2014}}</ref> Farmer managed to have her next birthday in comparative freedom, quietly.<ref>{{cite news | title =Miss Sarah H Farmer ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =22 Jul 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/655638/1915_july_22_sarah_farmer_observes_68th/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] praised the work freeing Farmer.<ref>{{cite journal | author =`Abdu'l-Bahá | authorlink =`Abdu'l-Bahá | title =Tablet to Mr. Vail | journal =Star of the West | volume =9 | issue =14 | page =155 | date =Nov 23, 1918 | origyear=Dec 27, 1916 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=155 | accessdate = Nov 28, 2014}}</ref> There was a session that summer at Green Acre.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Speaks on Scottish home rule | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =31 Jul 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2556424/scottish_home_rule_topic_of_chief/ | accessdate = June 5, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =eaks on Scottish home rule (continued) | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =31 Jul 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2556429/scottish_home_rule_topic_of_chief/ | accessdate =June 5, 2015 }}</ref>
The case was appealed questioning jurisdiction in the argument over guardians in late 1915.<ref>{{cite news | title =Transferred to supreme court | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =3 Dec 1915 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/654214/1915_dec_03_sarah_farmer_case/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =History of case | newspaper =Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =4 | date =4 Aug 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/648103/1916_aug_04_sarah_farmers_stay_in/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> The courts settled the case over guardianship against Sanborn's group in 1916.<ref name=Sanborn1916>{{cite news | title =Sanborn would have inquiry | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =24 Nov 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/649227/1916_nov_24_request_for_inquiry_into/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Meanwhile, the donation of Helen Cole in 1902 was set for building what became to be called the Fellowship House constructed in the middle 1916.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.108,165}}</small> Farmer was interviewed in the ''Boston Post'' in August during which the reporter had an experience he couldn't explain, (though there also several typos in the article and mis-labeling),<ref>{{cite news | title = How Sarah Farmer made Post writer sense the 'Presence' | newspaper =Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =53 | date =20 Aug 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/648146/1916_aug_20_how_sarah_farmer_made_post/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> and Farmer then died in November,<ref>{{cite news | title =Sarah J. Farmer dead | newspaper = The New York Times | location =New York, New York | page =13 | date =24 Nov 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/358587/1916_nov_24_obituary_for_sarah_j_farmer/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> while walking in her family cemetery.<ref name=Robinson2013/> There was a guard to protect her body lest it be taken.<ref>{{cite news | title =Noted as head of Greenacre | newspaper =The Telegraph | location =Nashua, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =Nov 24, 1916 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19161124&id=OtE_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=UKQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1288,1812665&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Sanborn called for an official inquiry of her death.<ref name=Sanborn1916/> The eulogy was read by Kate Ives and attending were Lunt, Ober and Randall among others of Boston and the area - Ober was noted an officer of Green Acre along with Lunt.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bahaists bury Miss Farmer | newspaper =Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =16 | date =27 Nov 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2060113/bahai_sarah_farmer_obit/ | accessdate = 24 Mar 2015}}</ref> With Farmer and her Will supporting the Bahá'ís the case ended. The transcendentalists school were, to put it mildly, upset, as were the supporters of the academic school.<ref name=Schmidt/><small>{{rp|pp.209–10,313–4}}</small><ref name=RichardsonOC/><ref name=Walter/> The Bahá'ís inherited the $25k in debt too.<ref name=Holley1955>{{cite news | author=Horace Holley | title =Green Acre background, letter to the editor | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location = Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =9 July 1955 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/286374/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate = January 17, 2014}}</ref> Though at the time the newspaper coverage was dismissive over her work,<ref name=Robinson2013/> modern coverage noted "She anticipated the peace movement, women's liberation and the New Age culture."<ref name=Robinson2013/> Farmer's contribution was considered a "singularly important" to the development of [[Bahá'í schools]].<ref name=Hutch&Holl>{{cite book|author1=Sandra Hutchinson|author2=Richard Hollinger | editor-last =Keller| editor-first = Rosemary Skinner | editor2-last = Ruether | editor2-first =Rosemary Radford | editor3-last =Cantlon | editor3-first = Marie |title=Encyclopedia of Women and Religion in North America: Native American creation stories | chapter =Women in the North American Baha'i Community | chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?id=WPILfbtT5tQC&pg=PA776 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WPILfbtT5tQC|year=2006|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-34687-8|pages=776–786}}</ref> Posthumously, [[Shoghi Effendi]], later head of the religion, appointed her as one of the [[Disciples of `Abdu'l-Bahá]].<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.88}} Bahá'ís noted her individual service as raising a status of organization vs institutionalization, setting a place for the rise of some of Americas' most active supporters of the religion, and the very nature of that place. However, liberal religious idealization noticed that a democratic system had awarded Green Acre to sectarian view.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Andrea Greenwood|author2=Mark W. Harris|title=An Introduction to the Unitarian and Universalist Traditions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OuGQuC4bcJgC&pg=PA110|date=11 August 2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-50453-9|pages=110–111}}</ref> It is true that before 1900 there were about a half dozen Bahá'ís in New England and that most of the growth of the religion in the region is attributed to the work done at Green Acre.<ref name=Stockman/><small>{{rp|pp.142–7}}</small>
There is no record of a summer session in 1916. Ober wrote a letter to the editor about the religion and Green Acre earlier in August.<ref>{{cite news | title =Relating to the Bahai movement | newspaper = Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =50 | date =27 Aug 1916 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/648106/1916_aug_27_letter_to_editor_about/ | accessdate = 12 Jun 2014}}</ref>
=== Green Acre and contributing to the national leadership===
{{further|Bahá'í administration}}
The 1917 Spring national convention of Bahá'ís with meetings held at Green Acre<ref name=300Baha>{{cite news | title =300 Bahaists to meet here | newspaper =Boston Post | location =Boston, Massachusetts | page =18 | date =25 Apr 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2060174/national_bahai_convention_alfred/ | accessdate = 24 Mar 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =International Bahai congress | newspaper =Laredo Weekly Times | location =Laredo, Texas | page =1 | date =29 Apr 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/256378/national_bahai_conference_at_boston/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }}</ref> and Boston.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bahaists meet Sunday in Boston | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =25 Apr 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2060167/national_bahai_convention_alfred/ | accessdate = 24 Mar 2015}}</ref> In 1917 William Randall was again elected to the national board of the religion and that year he was elected as president of the board<ref>{{cite news | title =Letter by the President of the Bahai Temple Unity |author=William H. Randall | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=8 |number=12 | page = 148 | date =Oct 16, 1917 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=148 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> and Harlan Ober was elected to the board as well.<ref>{{cite news | title =Membership of the Executive Board | newspaper = Star of the West |volume=8 |number=9 | pages =116–7 | date =Aug 20, 1917 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=116 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> Among the speakers on the summer schedule at Green Acre in 1917 were [[Horace Holley (Bahá'í)|Horace Holley]], Randall, Albert R. Vail, [[Louis G. Gregory]], Eshteal Ebn Kalanter, Lunt, and Albert Hall.<ref name=PH1917>{{cite news | title =Program for Green Acre Conferences | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =6 Aug 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2928926/green_acre_program_bahais_and_others/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> Randall spoke at Green Acre on "The mission of Green Acre" and another "Talks of `Abdu'l-Bahá" as well as others by Frederick Strong on several topics as well as Edward Getsinger.<ref>{{cite news | title =Opening of 24th season at Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =7 Jul 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/299228/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate = 22 Jan 2014}}</ref>
The military discussed taking over the Green Acre property for its workmen in 1918.<ref>{{cite news | title =May take over Eliot property for workmen | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =1 Mar 1918 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/886845/question_of_green_acre_bahai_school/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Randall was again elected to the national board of the religion, this time as treasurer, in 1918.<ref>{{cite news | title =First meeting of the new board of Bahai Temple Unity | author=Harlan Foster Ober | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=9 |number=6 | page =76 | date = June 24, 1918 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=76 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> Though the Inn did not open there was still a summer session with [[James Ferdinand Morton, Jr.|James F. Morton Jr.]] and a national [[Esperanto]] conference being held.<ref>* {{cite news | title =Green Acre opens season | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =11 Jul 1918 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/886858/green_acre_program_opens_summer_not/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Esperanto Congress in session | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =18 Jul 1918 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/886866/esperanto_congress_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> [[Martha Root]] attended.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.85}} And Mr and Mrs. Ober, Lunt, and [[May Maxwell]] were noted in the services for the funeral program for a close friend of Farmer who died.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre activities | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =27 Jul 1918 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/886895/funeral_of_bahai_helen_s_campbell/ | accessdate = 19 Aug 2014}}</ref> Randall along with [[Juliet Thompson]], [[May Maxwell]] and Albert Vail, debated the position of Green Acre on whether to raise the Peace Flag and ultimately decided it should be raised. Prayers were said at Green Acre to end World War I.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.91}}
Randall was on [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] after the war, in 1919 and `Abdu'l-Bahá encouraged him to continue the work of Farmer at Green Acre.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.91}} Randall served as the administrator of Green Acre from 1919 to 1929 when he died. Harlan Ober was at the 1919 national convention of Bahá'ís was held in New York.<ref>{{cite news | title =Pittsburgers will go to Bahai convention | newspaper =The Pittsburgh Press | location = Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | page =3 | date =Apr 20, 1919 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_0UbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k0kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4304%2C1235240 | accessdate = June 11, 2015 }}</ref> The 1919 convention was a major event in the religion because it was also the place the [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]] of `Abdu'l-Bahá were published.
Traveling teacher of the religion Fádil Mazandarání gave several talks at Green Acre in 1920.<ref name=Mazandari>{{cite web | author =compiled by Omeed Rameshni | title =Jináb-i-Fádil Mazandarání in the United States | publisher =bahai-library.com | year = 2009 | url =http://bahai-library.com/anon_mazandarani_united_states | accessdate = August 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre Conferences | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =1 | date =7 Aug 1920 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/297047/talk_at_bahai_green_acre_site_by_mirza/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Randall was elected to the national board again in 1920<ref>{{cite news | title =Third session of the convention |author=Louis G. Gregory | newspaper =Star of the West |volume= 11 |number=4 | pages =72–3 | date =May 17, 1920 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=72 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> as treasurer<ref>{{cite news | title =Thursday Morning Session April 29, 1920 |author=Alfred E. Lunt | newspaper = Star of the West |volume=11 |number=11 | page =199 | date =September 27, 1920 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=199 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> and addressed the convention.<ref>{{cite news | title =The Doors of the Kingdom are Open |author=William H. Randall |volume=11 |number=3 | newspaper =Star of the West | pages =43–44 | date =April 28, 1920 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=43 | accessdate =June 19, 2015 }}</ref> Randall was listed as the contact for announcing events and reserving rooms at Green Acre in 1920 by Albert Vail.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre in 1920 | newspaper =Star of the West | pages =92–3 | date =June 5, 1920 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=92 | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }}</ref>
Siegfried Schopflocher, later to become another [[Hand of the Cause]], joined the religion at Green Acre in 1921 and helped improve the property.<ref name=Hoonaard/><ref>{{cite web |last = van den Hoonaard | first =Will C. | title =Schopflocher, Siegfried | work =draft of ''The Baha'i Encyclopedia'' | publisher =Bahai-library.com | date =June 1993 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hoonaard_encyclopedia_siegfried_schopflocher | accessdate = August 1, 2015 }}</ref> A Tea House and gift shop were established.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.92}} Paul Haney and [[May Maxwell]] were also known at the facility in 1921.<ref name=Francis1998>{{cite web | last =Francis | first = Richard | title =Haney, Paul | publisher =Bahai-library.com | year =1998 | url =http://bahai-library.com/francis_haney_biography | accessdate = August 1, 2015 }}</ref> A major memorial for the death of `Abdu'l-Bahá was held in 1922.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre Conferences |author=Martha Root | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald, | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | pages =4 | date = 15 August 1922 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/268942/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> Otherwise there is no known program in 1921. In 1922 a program was carried on by Louis Gregory, Albert Watson, Juliet Putnam, George Latimer, Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Randagger, Mrs. E. Boye, W H Randall.<ref name=PH1922>{{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =22 Jul 1922 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3100027/1922_green_acre_program/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> Randall was appointed to the supervisory board of the Bahá'í periodical ''Star of the West'' in 1922,<ref>{{cite news | title =Change of management of the ''Star of the West'' |author1=Albert R. Windust |author2= Gertrude Buikema | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=13 |number=4 | page =80 | date =May 17, 1922 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=13&page=80 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> and contributed an article on Green Acre.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre |author=William H. Randall | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=13 |number=5 | pages = 110–111 | date =August 1922 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=13&page=110 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> In 1923 he was noted as chairman of the board of Green Acre<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre for over thirty years ... | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=14 |number=4 | page =123 | date =July 1923 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=14&page=123 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> while continuing as treasurer<ref>{{cite news | title =Building the Bahai Temple the Universal Way | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=13 |number= 11 | page = 313 | date =Feb 1923 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=13&page=313 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> for the newly designated National Spiritual Assembly.<ref>{{cite news | title =The spirit of the convention; Second Day |author= Louis G. Gregory | newspaper =Star of the West |volume= 14 |number= 3 | pages =77–78 | date =June 1923 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=14&page=78 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> A general renovation was begun in 1921 and completed in 1924 - repairs, painting, and clearing away scrub growth, etc., was done.<ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre - a summer paradise | author=George Orr Latimer | newspaper =Star of the West, | volume =15 | number=3 | pages =79–80 | date =June 1924 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=15&page=79 | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A program went on in 1923 with Fádil Mazandarání giving a talk,<ref name=Mazandari/> among the program that summer.<ref name=Atkinson1990/><ref>{{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =21 Jul 1923 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/297064/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> The "Eirenion" burned down in 1924,<ref>{{cite news | title =Greenacre Assembly hall burns, $5,000 | newspaper =Lewiston Evening Journal | location = Lewiston, Maine | page =3 | date =Jul 16, 1924 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1913&dat=19240716&id=gokgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=M2UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6291,1164499&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> right before the summer season of Green Acre was held with an international theme and presence and the first appearance of Glenn A. Shook, professor of [[Wheaton College (Massachusetts)]].<ref>* {{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =23 Aug 1924 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703616/green_acre_hosts_writers_eirenion/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =27 Aug 1924 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703628/talks_recitals_reception_at_green/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
In 1925 there were a number of developments. First the national convention was held at Green Acre.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.94}} Famous African-American leader [[Alain Locke]], a Bahá'í since 1918, spoke at the 1925 convention.<ref name=Buck-Locke>{{cite book|author=Christopher Buck|title=Alain Locke: Faith and Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JR_DF2MRlsIC&pg=PA119|year=2005|publisher=Kalimat Press|isbn=978-1-890688-38-7|pages= 64, 119–120, 137–138, 143, 174, 198}}</ref> Second, the national election was held under new rules fully endorsed by the head of the religion. That year a local assembly was elected for the first time in Eliot.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.94}} And lastly it was announced the administrative offices of the religion would be run from Green Acre.<ref>{{cite news | title =National Bahai office at Eliot | newspaper = The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =31 Oct 1925 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/269145/national_convention_of_bahais_at/ | accessdate = June 2, 2015 }}</ref> The members of the Eliot local assembly were - [[Horace Holley (Bahá'í)|Horace]] and Doris Holley, Kate Ives, Ivy Drew Edwards, Marion Jack, Colonel Henry and Mary Culver, Ella Roberts and Phillip Marangella. Lunt was noted on the board of trustees of Green Acre.<ref>{{cite news | title =Improvements at Green Acre are planned | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =10 | date =11 Aug 1925 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2556454/bahai_william_h_randall_chair_and/ | accessdate = 5 Jun 2015}}</ref> Bahá'í Mary Lucas who had performed at Green Acre several times held her professional school for singers there.<ref>{{cite news | title =Mme. Mary L. Lucas, Teacher ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =8 | date =3 Jun 1925 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2703560/bahai_mary_lucas_singing_teacher_at/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
While the history of [[persecution of Bahá'ís]] in Persia goes back some many years the first known newspaper mention in the area was in 1926.<ref>{{cite news | title =Persia persecuting Bahaists | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =6 | date =13 Aug 1926 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2062140/persia_persecution_of_bahais_notice/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> That summer the program was "Green Acre Summer School of World Unity" in August.<ref name=TMTW>{{cite book | title = To move the world : Louis G. Gregory and the advancement of racial unity in America | last = Morrison | first = Gayle | publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust | location = Wilmette, Ill |year = 1982 | isbn = 0-87743-188-4}}</ref>{{rp|p.159}} But the National Assembly acquired direct authority of the Green Acre establishment.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.166}} At the same time the national assembly began a "Plans of Unified Action" process that included a plan to centralize all Bahá'í funding of projects through one national fund including Green Acre resulting in a learning process for the assembly and the community in maintaining priorities in a nationwide context - a process that extended into the 1930s during the [[Great Depression]].<ref name="Smith2004">{{cite book|editor=Peter Smith|author=Loni Bramson|title=Bahá'ís in the West|chapter=The Plans of Unified Action: A Survey|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&pg=PA155|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC|year=2004|publisher=Kalimat Press|isbn=978-1-890688-11-0|pages=16, 170–197}}</ref> Education reformer [[Stanwood Cobb]] established "Mast Cove Camp" at Eliot that year too.<ref>{{cite news | title =Discovering the Genius within you |author=Stanwood Cobb | newspaper =Lewiston Evening Journal | location = Lewiston, Maine | page =8 | date =Mar 19, 1932 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1913&dat=19320319&id=lBRKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GR4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1401,5974788&hl=en | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref>
===Programs and model=== In 1927 Green Acre hosted its first [[Race Amity Convention]] in mid-July<ref name=Buck-Locke/> following an initiative push by [[Shoghi Effendi]], then head of the religion, in April.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.175}}<ref name=Etter-Lewis2006>{{cite book|author1=Gwendolyn Etter-Lewis|author2=Richard Thomas|author3=Richard Walter Thomas|title=Lights of the Spirit: Historical Portraits of Black Bahá'ís in North America, 1898–2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L2KVX4mx1xEC&pg=PA186|year=2006|publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust|isbn=978-1-931847-26-1|pages=33–36, 186–189, 251–256}}</ref> The first convention had been held in Washington D.C. in 1921 followed by a lapse, and this 1927 convention was arranged by a committee appointed by the US Bahá'í National Spiritual Assembly - Agnes Parsons, Coralie F. Cook, [[Louis Gregory]], Zia Bagdadi, [[Alain Locke]], Elizabeth G. Hopper and Isabel Ives, (though Locke appears on the program he did not actually speak at the convention.)<ref name=Buck-Locke/> Prominent contributors at the convention included [[Devere Allen]] of [[The World Tomorrow (magazine)|The World Tomorrow]], Samuel McComb of the [[Emmanuel Movement]], Rev. William Stafford Jones and recent pilgrims Edwina Powell and S. E. J. Oglesby.<ref name=Etter-Lewis2006/> According to Louis Gregory he had to chair one of the sessions "so that the affair would not be too one-sided" in the face of low participation despite "a little under-current of bad feeling" among some Bahá'ís.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.212}} This proved the first of a series of annual race amity conferences.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.181}} However, the event turned out to be so successful that money from the national budget to support the event was in fact covered by generous individuals caught up in the event and instead the allotment of about $400,<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.186}}(alittle over $5400 in 2014 dollars,)<ref name=inflation/> was returned to be contributed to the costs for building the American Bahá'í Temple.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.184}} There was a peace program the following August.<ref>{{cite news | title =Peace Conference delegate | newspaper =The Pittsburgh Courier | location =Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | page =6 | date =20 Aug 1927 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/406717/mrs_henry_payne_goes_to_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref>
The success of Green Acre as a Bahá'í institution began to inspire other regional schools for the religion: first came [[Bosch Bahá'í School]] becoming more formally a Bahá'í school in 1927 and another in 1931 at [[Louhelen Bahá'í School]].<ref name=Hutch&Holl/>
The pace of race amity meetings continued nationwide for Bahá'ís into 1928 when it was again held at Green Acre in August.<ref name=TMTW/><small>{{rp|pp.183–4}}</small> Randall also took part in it.<ref>{{cite news | title =Can the races harmonize? |author =Louis G. Gregory | newspaper =Star of the West |volume=19 |number=8 | pages =248–252 | date =Nov 1928 | url =http://starofthewest.info/viewer.erb?vol=19&page=232 | accessdate = June 19, 2015}}</ref> Perhaps Randall's final appearance was August 1928 at a commemoration of the visit of `Abdu'l-Bahá to Green Acre.<ref>{{cite news | title =In Memory of the visit of Abdul Baha | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =21 Aug 1928 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/269297/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate =9 Jan 2014}}</ref> Randall died Feb 11, 1929.<ref name=RandallObit/> Meanwhile, in 1928 Ober gave a talk in Brooklyn,<ref>{{cite news | title =Bahai | newspaper =The Brooklyn Daily Eagle | location =Brooklyn, New York | page =5 | date =23 Jun 1928 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2593501/bahai_harlan_ober_gives_talk_at_center/ | accessdate = 11 Jun 2015}}</ref> and Grace hosted an evening social at Green Acre.<ref>{{cite news | title =Hold Eliot Night at Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =4 | date =1 Sep 1928 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/382089/1928_sept_01_mrs_harlan_ober_hostess_at/ | accessdate = 26 Feb 2014}}</ref> That year the official board of Green Acre, the "Fellowship", formally deeded Green Acre to a trustees appointed by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States.<ref name=Holley1955/> Lunt served on the national assembly that year.<ref>{{cite news | title =At Green Acre | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =21 Aug 1928 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1929388/bahai_national_assembly_conference/ | accessdate = 5 Mar 2015}}</ref>

===1943=== 1943 was a year of race riots around the United States - the [[Beaumont race riot of 1943]] of mid-June, the [[Detroit race riot of 1943]] of late June, and the [[Harlem riot of 1943]] of early August. Profiles of the religion's teaching of race unity had been highlighted by Alice Simmons Cox in ''The New York Age'' in the winter-spring<ref>* {{cite news | title =America's new unity |author= Alice Simmon Cox | newspaper =The New York Age | location =New York, NY | page =6 | date =26 Dec 1942 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/286478/alice_simmons_cox_profiles_bahai_faith/ | access-date = Nov 23, 2017 }} * {{cite news | title =Education for race unity |author=Alice Simmon Cox | newspaper =The New York Age | location =New York, NY | page =9 | date =17 Apr 1943 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/286486/the_new_york_age/ | access-date = Nov 23, 2017 }}</ref> Dorothy Beecher Baker had a talk series including the subject of race unity in Rochester, NY, in late July<ref>{{cite news | title =Leader of Bahai visits Rochester | newspaper =Democrat and Chronicle | location =Rochester, NY | page =4 | date =31 Jul 1943 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/14637518/bahai_dorothy_beecher_baker_talk/ | access-date = Nov 23, 2017 }}</ref> just before the Green Acre summer session and Mrs. Charles Witt talk on race unity over in Los Angeles, CA.<ref>{{cite news | title =Baha'i service tells divine prophet need | newspaper =The Los Angeles Times | location =Los Angeles, CA | page =22 | date =2 Aug 1943 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6272851/brief_review_of_talk_by_bahai_mrs/ | access-date = Nov 23, 2017 }}</ref> Ober was one among several present in a August series of talks at Green Acre - Mary Coristine, Philip Sprague, Lorraine Welsh, Lorna Tasker, Mary McClendon, Gertrude Atkinson, Louis Gregory, Horace Holley, Mrs Ali Kuli Khan, Hesmat Ala'i, Maud Mickle, and Mabel Jenkins all contributed on topics of equality of women and unity of humanity,<ref>{{cite news | title =Woman's struggle for equality explained at Green Acre by Mrs. Mary Coristine | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =11 | date =10 Aug 1943 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/845399/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate = 11 Aug 2014}}</ref> with the largest attendance of the season,<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.278}} partly from a nationwide call for the prominence of the topic,<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.284}} while the late August session also featured a review of the life of Muhammad.<ref>{{cite news | title =Speaker at Green Acre reviews life of Mohammed | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =1 Sep 1943 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/845411/the_portsmouth_herald/ | accessdate =11 Aug 2014 }}</ref> The National assembly had set in motion a series of efforts in anticipation of the Centenary of the Declaration of the Báb,<ref>{{cite magazine | title =Letter from the National Spiritual Assembly | magazine =Bahá'í News |issue=165 | pages =1–2 | date =Sep 1943 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=02&page=582 | access-date = Nov 23, 2017 }}</ref> saying the situation of race in the country "demands our devoted attention and endeavor throughout September and October, the fundamental teaching of the Faith, its most challenging principle, its swift healing antidote for the ills of a divided world." There was a specific attempt to reach the public, and on the subject of the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of humanity|oneness of mankind]] - race unity. The conference achieved some newspaper publicity,<ref>* {{cite magazine | title =Oneness of humanity keynote of Green Acre Conclave | magazine =Bahá'í News |issue= 168 | pages =4–5 | date =Nov 1943 | ===1950s=== Green Acre Bahá'í School was reopened in 1951<ref name=Atkinson1990/> thanks in part to youth groups working on getting the facility ready.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.114}}
====Louis G. Gregory==== {{main|Louis G. Gregory}}[[File:Louis-and-Louisa-Gregory.png|Louis-and-Louisa-Gregory|thumbnail|right|Louis G. and Louisa Mathew Gregory]]
[[Louis G. Gregory]] went to Green Acre in the fall of 1911 for the first time - it was just a few months after his return from [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]].<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.49}}<ref>{{cite news | title =Mr. Gregory goes East | newspaper =The Appeal | location =Saint Paul, Minnesota | page =2 | date =19 Aug 1911 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3099611/bahai_louis_g_gregory_on_speaking/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> In 1912 he married Louise Matthews. He was next known at Green Acre in 1917 when he gave a talk "Prophetic proofs of the Baha'i Revelation."<ref name=PH1917/> In 1920 the Gregories were able to spend some ten days together after many months each traveling in different directions for the religion amidst a time where inter-racial marriage was socially troubled and he was "so onerous and irritable, so unlike himself" that his wife was in despair over his condition - nevertheless he set out on the longest of his teaching tours the following year.<ref name=TMTW/><small>{{rp|pp.91,117}}</small> From then on most summers they were able to be in the environment at Eliot and it became their "home base".<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.185}} In 1922, while a member of the National Spiritual Assembly, he chaired the summer program and gave two talks at Green Acre - "Prayer and Praise", and "The [[Tablet of the Holy Mariner|Holy Mariner]]".<ref name=PH1922/><ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.122}} They were there in 1923.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.123}} He attended the organizing 1925 national convention held at Green Acre.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.93}} The 1926 summer program at Green Acre had Gregory as co-director with Albert Vail and Howard MacNutt.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.160}} They were there in June 1929 before the Green Acre program started.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.186}} Like many leaders in the religion, the Gregories began to serve over seas for extended periods in the 1930s - Louise in Europe at first and then the both of them in Haiti.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.246}} The Gregorys returned to Green Acre in 1938 but wintered in Cambridge.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.254}}
In 1940 the Gregories bought a different summer cottage in Eliot,<ref>{{cite news | title =Eliot; Mrs. Louis Gregory ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =5 Jun 1940 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3099851/gregory_bahai_residence_in_eliot/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> and a winter apartment in Portsmouth.<ref>{{cite news | title =Prof. and Mrs. Louis Gregory ... | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =6 | date =26 Nov 1940 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3099863/gregory_residence_bahais_in/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> A small community held [[Nineteen Day Feast]] in September 1941.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bahai Feast held | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =10 | date =10 Sep 1941 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3099876/bahai_feast_held_in_eliot_ella/ | accessdate = August 28, 2015}}</ref> Gregory served several years on the Green Acre school committee itself in the 1940s<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.297}} and loved to work with children's classes.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|pp.298–9}} From 1946, now that Louise was over eighty years old and less independent, Gregory stayed more at home than traveling the country as he had done for decades.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.305}} Both his race and their inter-racial marriage seemed well accepted in Eliot. Friends often saw them on the porch or at events in Green Acre and their garden was doing well at home.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.305}}
In December 1948 Gregory suffered a stroke a couple months after returning from a funeral for a friend<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.306}}<ref name=Venters>{{Cite thesis | last =Venters | first =Louis E., the III | title =Most great reconstruction: The Baha'i faith in Jim Crow South Carolina, 1898–1965 | publisher = Colleges of Arts and Sciences University of South Carolina | year = 2010 | url =http://bahai-library.com/venters_bahai_south_carolina | isbn = 978-1-243-74175-2 | id = UMI Number: 3402846}}</ref> and between him and his wife, whose health also declined, began to stay closer to home. His recovery was more than the doctor predicted when a couple months later he had regained his hand-writing though slanted.<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|pp.306–7}} By the summer of 1949 he was again carrying on an active correspondence. In particular Gregory carried on correspondence with U.S. District Court Judge [[Julius Waties Waring]] and his wife in 1950–51 who was involved in [[Briggs v. Elliott]] even while Green Acre was closed for austerity.
Gregory died aged seventy-seven on July 30, 1951. He is buried at Eliot and just a few days later during the memorial service a telegram arrived stating he was appointed as one of the [[Hands of the Cause]], the highest office open to individuals in the religion, by then head of the religion, [[Shoghi Effendi]].<ref name=TMTW/>{{rp|p.310}}

In 1952 the room `Abdu'l-Bahá's used while staying there was set aside for prayers and meditation.<ref name=Atkinson1990/>
Legal cases began to question the roll of Green Acre as a religious institution and its status for tax reasons.<ref name=WagnerLegal>{{cite web | author =compiled by Ralph D. Wagner | title =Green Acre Bahá'í Institute vs. Town of Eliot, Maine | publisher =Bahai-Library.com | orig-year =1954 |date=1963 | url =http://bahai-library.com/green_acre_vs_eliot | accessdate = August 2, 2015 }}</ref> In 1954 the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine ruled that the Green Acre Bahá'í Institute was entitled to tax exemption as a charitable institution.<ref name=WagnerLegal/><ref>{{cite news | title =Green Acre Baha'i Institute entitled to tax abatement rules Maine Supreme Court | newspaper =Lewiston Evening Journal | location = Lewiston, Maine | page =1 | date =Dec 23, 1954 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1913&dat=19541223&id=wAtHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t_MMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4621,5755046&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Horace Holley made public some material on the legal timeline of Green Acre in 1955 sharing information affecting its tax status.<ref name=Holley1955/> Nathan Rutstein lived at Green Acre in the summer of 1955 with his new wife before getting into television production and appointed as a [[Continental Counselors|Auxiliary Board member]] for the religion.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nathan Rutstein|title=From a Gnat to an Eagle: The Story of Nathan Rutstein|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aR2AIrHGrH4C&pg=PA85|date=1 January 2008|publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust|isbn=978-1-931847-46-9|pages=85–88, 177}}</ref>
===1960s - 1990s=== In the 1960s, the first full-time staff of the school and the first year-round live-in caretaker were hired - Stuart Rhode and Emma Rice.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> The first full-time property manager, Edwin Miller was hired in the 1970s.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> Emma Rice, former [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]] for Sicily, became the resident caretaker of the Fellowship House.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.167}} The tax status of Green Acre Baha'i Institute was contested in 1963 and the same court removed the tax exemption, based on a 1957 law limiting exemptions to institutions that primarily serve residents of Maine.<ref name=WagnerLegal/> Richard Grover grew into the first full-time administrator of Green Acre in the 1980s.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> The administration of Green Acre transferred to Ray Labelle around 1990 and then James and Jeannine Sacco in 1995-96.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> Later, in 1997, the US Supreme Court declared the Maine law unconstitutional reverting the tax status of Green Acre.<ref name=WagnerLegal/> Green Acre became recognized as "paradigmatic of a Bahá'í institution".<ref name=Hutch&Holl/>
A variety of individuals visited in the 1960 and into the 1970s in addition to regular presenters. The 1960 session included [[Firuz Kazemzadeh]].<ref>{{cite news | title =Baha'i Names Teachers for Green Acres | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =16 | date =7 July 1960 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/260889/firuz_kazemzadeh_teaching_at_green_acre/ | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> A [[Pennacook]] Indian, Gerard Morin aka Little Bishop, presented on local Indian culture in Green Acre in 1966.<ref>{{cite news | title ='Little Bishop' lectures to Maine Baha'is | newspaper =The Telegraph | location =Nashua, New Hampshire | page =7 | date =Jul 30, 1966 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19660730&id=yawrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Vv0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=7041,2939687&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Hand of the Cause [[Ali Akbar Furutan]] visited in 1969.<ref>{{cite news | title =Hand of Cause to visit Geyserville Baha'i School | newspaper = The Geyserville Press | location = Geyserville, California | page =9 | date =Aug 21, 1969 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1024&dat=19690821&id=VuEkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HhAGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3816,102240&hl=en | accessdate = August 7, 2015 }}</ref> Hand of the Cause [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]] visited in 1978 with his wife Marguerite Reimer Sears as part of establishing the Reimer award for service to Green Acre.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.116–7}}</small> Its first recipient was Emma Rice.
It was also during the 1960s that the first Bahá'í studies of the history of Sarah Farmer, Green Acre, and Monsalvat took place by Douglas Martin and H.T.D. Rost.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> This was extended in the 1980s with occasional lectures entitled Farmer Family Memorial Lectures began,<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.117}} while Kenneth Walter published a polemical compilation of the rise and fall of transcendentalism at Green Acre in 1980 recalling the vehemence against the Bahá'ís.<ref name=Walter/> The Association for Bahá'í Studies held its first regional conference at Green Acre in 1983.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> Sessions began to be held preserving Green Acre history and in 1986 the National Spiritual Assembly made the restoration of the Sarah Farmer Inn a goal for the Bahá'ís of the Northeast.<ref name=Atkinson1990/> In 1989 local chapters of peace groups offered programs at Green Acre, and centennial observances began starting with its inception in 1890.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.118}} Restoration of the Sarah Farmer Inn continued for many years as funds became available and was finally completed in summer of 1994,<ref name=Atkinson1990/> the centennial of the first Greenacre Meeting entitled "100 Years for Peace" commemorated with a post office cancelation and some 1500 guests (greater than the population of the town of Eliot when the site opened.)<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.118–9}}</small> Some 300 attended program of the Vedanta Society to commemorate Swami Vivekenda's presence in 1894 with a plaque along with publishing a collection of poetry, ''Voice of Lovers''.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.119}} Bahá'í academies and training sessions by the Bahá'í International Community office at the United Nations were held in the 1990s.
In 1998 the institution of the "Black Men's gathering" began annual meetings at Green Acre Bahá'í School after being hosted at [[Louis Gregory Bahá'í Institute]] and other places until it ended in 2011. Each year the group walked in procession to Gregory's gravesite.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.119,169}}</small><ref>{{cite AV media | people = | title =Done Made My Vow to the Lord: The Baha'i Black Men's Gathering 1987 - 2011 | medium =documentary | publisher =National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | date =2013 | url =https://vimeo.com/74769779 }}</ref>{{rp|4:41m}} Green Acre Bahá'í School has also been home to the annual "Turning 15 Academy"/"Badasht Prep Academy"/"Badasht Academy" (variously named and often named after the [[Conference of Badasht]]) since the summer of 1999 as a week-long intensive study of Bahá'í history and religious practices.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.119}}<ref>{{cite news | title =January programs | newspaper =January 2011 Green Acre eNewsletter | location =Eliot, Maine | page =1 | publisher =Greenacre.org | date =January 2011 | url =http://myemail.constantcontact.com/January-2011-Green-Acre-eNewsletter.html?soid=1101212188982&aid=c6aZk-SyjIs | accessdate = August 23, 2015 }}</ref>
===Since 2000=== [[File:Inn at Green Acre Baha'i School 01.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Sarah Farmer Inn at Green Acre, November 2017.]] In 2000 [[Ruhi Institute]] courses were offered.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.120}} Observances memorializing the deaths in [[9-11]] were held in cooperation with the Eliot public library and the local congregational church. In 2002 the old Baha'i Hall was taken down and replaced the same year with the Curtis and Harriet Kelsey Center<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.120}} which featured an auditorium for 220 seats and seven classrooms.<ref>{{cite news | title =New classroom building dedicated at Green Acre Baha'i School | newspaper =Baha'i World News Service | publisher =Baha'i International Community | date =21 September 2002 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/175 | accessdate = August 23, 2015}}</ref> Noted scholar on Khalil Gibran, [[Suheil Bushrui]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Kahlil Gibran, Man and Poet: a New Biography|year=1998|publisher=Oneworld Publications|author=Bushrui, Suheil B.|author2=Jenkins, Joe|page=55|isbn=978-1851682676| url=http://bahai-library.com/bushrui_gibran_man_poet}}</ref> spoke at Green Acre Bahá'í school in 2003 giving a two-day course on `Abdu'l-Bahá's teachings on peace.<ref>{{cite news | last =Elliott | first = Chris | title =Scholar shares vision of world peace | newspaper =Portsmouth Herald | location =New Hampshire | year = 2003 | url =http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/2003/030512-2.html | accessdate = August 1, 2015 }}</ref> Renovations and expansion at Green Acre as part of an investment across all the Bahá'í schools was initiated in 2000 under the name "Kingdom Project" and finished in 2005.<ref name="McMullenMcMullen2015">{{cite book|author1=Mike McMullen|author2=Michael McMullen|title=The Bahá'ís of America: The Growth of a Religious Movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iecWCgAAQBAJ|date=27 November 2015|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-1-4798-5152-2|pages=223–229}}</ref>
In 2004 a commemorative [[peace garden]] was established at the School and the property of the home of the Gregory's was added to the holdings of Green Acre Bahá'í School in Eliot.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.121}}
In 2005 the centenary of the Portsmouth Peace Treaty and Farmer's involvement was established in a Sarah Farmer Peace Award by the Bahá'ís of Eliot and has been given out annually<ref>{{cite web | title =Award Recipients | publisher = Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Eliot, ME | date =2013 | url =http://sarahfarmerpeaceaward.org/recipients.html | accessdate = August 23, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Santoski | first = Teresa | title =Amherst filmmaker explores religious principles behind Portsmouth Peace Treaty | newspaper =The Telegraph Encore | location =Nashua, NH | date =January 12, 2012 | url = http://www.encorebuzz.com/entertainment/946145-249/amherst-filmmaker-explores-religious-principles-behind-portsmouth.html?CSAuthResp=1234%3A%3A5000%3A257%3A24%3Aapproved%3A748801ABF57441070238AEAD407A5FAA | accessdate = August 23, 2015 }}</ref> and [[Ryozo Kato]], Japanese Ambassador to the United States in 2005, made an official visit to Green Acre commemorating the treaty.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.122}} The events were held included re-enactments for Theodore Roosevelt, Ida B. Wells, Thomas Edison, William Jennings Bryan, and Fred Harvey as well as Sarah Farmer herself, along with contributions from speakers, writers and artists were held at Green Acre Bahá'í School itself as well as a meeting of the Association of Bahá'í Studies of the US and Canada.<ref name=Perry2012/><small>{{rp|pp.123–9}}</small>
The School also continued to network with the area chapter of the [[NAACP]].<ref>{{cite web| title =Recent History| work =| publisher =NAACP of the Seacoast| year =2005| url =http://www.seacoastnaacp.com/recenthistory.cfm| accessdate = November 1, 2013 }}</ref>
In 2007 sessions included the sitting [[University of Maryland College of Behavioral and Social Sciences#Faculty|Chair for Peace]] from the University of Maryland, Dr. John Grayzel, gave a class with the chair of the Portsmouth Peace Treaty Anniversary Committee.<ref name=Perry2012/>{{rp|p.132}}
The Eliot 2010 bicentenary was celebrated and there was a play at Green Acre as part of it.<ref>{{cite web | title =Eliot's Bicentennial Celebration Remembered | publisher =Town of Eliot, Maine | url =http://www.eliotmaine.org/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC=%7B6A7CCF47-DC5A-487D-A2BE-5D70AA44064D%7D | accessdate = August 23, 2015 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120531002138/http://www.eliotmaine.org/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC=%7B6A7CCF47-DC5A-487D-A2BE-5D70AA44064D%7D | archivedate =May 31, 2012 }}</ref> Green Acre was also reviewed in line with other movements of the turn of the 20th century in a documentary about peace activism related to the [[Treaty of Portsmouth]]<ref>{{cite news| last =Santoski| first = Teresa| title =Amherst filmmaker explores religious principles behind Portsmouth Peace Treaty| newspaper =The Telegraph Encore| location =Nashua, NH| date =January 12, 2012| url = http://www.encorebuzz.com/entertainment/946145-249/amherst-filmmaker-explores-religious-principles-behind-portsmouth.html?CSAuthResp=1234%3A%3A5000%3A257%3A24%3Aapproved%3A748801ABF57441070238AEAD407A5FAA| accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref> and was premiered on the campus in 2012 during the centenary of `Abdu'l-Bahá's visit.<ref>{{cite journal| title =Community Briefs; The Peace Treaty in Portsmouth| journal =The York Independent| volume =12| issue =14| page =6| date =July 16–20, 2010| url =http://www.yorkindependent.net/TYI_0716.pdf| accessdate = November 1, 2013}}</ref> Four more buildings were dedicated after a four-year construction project: the Harry Randall Guest House, Louise and Louisa Gregory Cottage, Mildred and Rafi Mottahedeh Cottage, and Emma Rice Cottage replacing four of the older cottages on the property.<ref>{{cite news | last =Pechenik | first = Mark | title =Green Acre Baha'i School celebrates four new buildings | newspaper =seacoastonline.com | date =September 19, 2012 | url = http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20120919-NEWS-209190355 | accessdate = August 23, 2015}}</ref> In Washington D. C. a commemorative tour recalled Stanwood Cobb's association with Green Acre and Eliot.<ref>{{cite web |title = Cobb House |work = |publisher = DC Bahá'í Tour |year = 2012 |url = http://www.dcbahaitour.org/place/?id=31 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131103110038/http://www.dcbahaitour.org/place/?id=31 |archivedate = November 3, 2013 |df = }}</ref>
Don Tennant appreciated living in the atmosphere of honesty at Green Acre while he wrote ''Spy the lie'', published in 2012, while his wife worked at Green Acre.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Philip Houston|author2=Michael Floyd|author3=Susan Carnicero |author4=Don Tennant|title=Spy the Lie: Former CIA Officers Teach You How to Detect Deception|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FG1tAwAAQBAJ&pg=PR12|date=16 July 2013|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1-250-02962-1|pages=xii–xiii}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media | people =Don Tennant | title =Don Tennant on WCSH Portland's 207 | medium =television | publisher =WCSH6.com | location =Eliot, Maine | date =Jul 24, 2012 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yQGQInwN818}}</ref>
